choices.text: Increase in preload causes more reduction in myocardial oxygen demand than increase in afterload
Workload is independent of myocardial oxygen consumption
Aortic stenosis results in lower pressure compared to aortic valve
Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is more significant with pressure overload than volume overload

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea and chest pain on exertion. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids. Echocardiography confirms the presence of aortic stenosis. Which of the following findings best distinguishes aortic stenosis from aortic regurgitation in terms of myocardial oxygen consumption?
questions.solution:
Myocardial oxygen consumption increases more significantly in pressure overload (as in aortic stenosis) than in volume overload (as in aortic regurgitation).

  • Aortic stenosis (AS) leads to pressure overload on the left ventricle due to obstruction of blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve.
  • This pressure overload results in concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, which increases myocardial wall tension and oxygen demand.
  • The myocardium has to work harder to overcome the elevated pressure gradient across the valve, leading to a significant increase in myocardial oxygen consumption.
  • In contrast, aortic regurgitation (AR) primarily causes volume overload, resulting in eccentric hypertrophy.
  • Although this also increases myocardial workload, the oxygen demand rises more steeply in pressure overload than in volume overload, making this distinction important in clinical practice.
  • This explains why patients with aortic stenosis can develop angina even in the absence of coronary artery disease-due to a mismatch between the high oxygen demand of the hypertrophied myocardium and the compromised coronary blood flow.

Explanation of other options:

Increase in preload causes more reduction in myocardial oxygen demand than increase in afterload (Option A): Incorrect. Preload increases tend to augment stroke volume, but do not reduce myocardial oxygen demand. In fact, increased afterload (as in AS) raises oxygen demand more significantly.

Workload is independent of myocardial oxygen consumption (Option B): Incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly proportional to the workload of the heart, especially in terms of pressure or volume stress.

Aortic stenosis results in lower pressure compared to aortic valve (Option C): Incorrect. Aortic stenosis causes increased intraventricular pressure due to obstruction at the aortic valve, not reduced pressure.

questions.text: A lesion in the Brodmann area 22 will cause:
questions.solution:
Brodmann area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's area, located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left). A lesion in this area causes Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia, characterised by impaired comprehension and fluent but meaningless speech (word salad).


Explanation for other options:

Expressive aphasia (Option A): Expressive aphasia (Broca's aphasia) results from a lesion in Brodmann area 44 & 45 (Broca's area), causing non-fluent speech with intact comprehension.

Poor repetition of language (Option C): This is characteristic of conduction aphasia, which occurs due to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, disrupting communication between Wernicke's and Broca's areas.

Poor naming (Option D): While naming impairment can occur, it is not specific to Wernicke's aphasia; anomic aphasia primarily affects naming ability.

Reference:

  1. Aphasia
  2. Conduction Aphasia

questions.text: Which ion is the most responsible one for the resting membrane potential?
questions.solution:
Potassium ions are the primary contributors to the resting membrane potential. The RMP is mainly determined by the K+ gradient across the cell membrane, as potassium ions move out of the cell through potassium leak channels.

  • The loss of positively charged K+ ions from the cell creates a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside, establishing the RMP, which is typically around -70 mV in neurons.

Resting membrane potential (RMP):

  • It is defined as the voltage difference between the exterior and interior of an excitable cell
  • In any cell, K+ is the major determinant of RMP
  • The major contribution of RMP is through passive diffusion of K+ ions, followed by active diffusion through Na+-K+ ions.

Generation of RMP:

questions.text: Which of the following given diseases has the maximum portion of the iceberg submerged?
questions.solution:
Influenza has the maximum submerged portion of the iceberg because a large number of infected individuals may be asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms, resulting in underreporting and unrecognised cases. This large reservoir of mild or asymptomatic cases contributes significantly to the spread of the disease.

Iceberg phenomenon of disease:

  • It suggests that some diseases have a significant portion of undiagnosed or asymptomatic cases, while only a small portion is diagnosed and visible.
  • The "tip of the iceberg" denotes diagnosed cases or apparent infections of concern to physicians, where diagnostic tests are applied.
  • The "hidden portion" includes undiagnosed or asymptomatic individuals of concern to epidemiologists, who may appear healthy but harbour the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presents with fever and tenderness in the left lower limb. The limb is warm to the touch, and ESR is raised. An X-ray reveals periosteal elevation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, localized warmth, raised ESR, and periosteal elevation on X-ray are classic indicators of acute osteomyelitis.

  • Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, commonly caused by pyogenic bacteria in children.
  • caused by pyogenic bacteria in children. The metaphysis of long bones is the usual site due to its rich vascular supply and sluggish blood flow, which predisposes to bacterial seeding.
  • Clinically, it presents with fever, localized pain, warmth, tenderness, and systemic signs of infection.
  • Raised ESR and CRP are common laboratory findings. On radiography, periosteal elevation appears by 7-10 days due to subperiosteal abscess formation.
  • Early radiographs may be normal, so MRI is more sensitive in the early phase (within 24 hours) as it can detect bone marrow edema.
  • Confirmation of diagnosis is through aspiration and culture of the infected site.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing sarcoma (Option A): A malignant small round cell tumor seen in children and adolescents; presents with fever, pain, and swelling but is less likely to show acute signs of infection like warmth and raised ESR early. Onion-skin periosteal reaction is more characteristic.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Malignant bone tumor of adolescence; typically presents with pain and swelling. X-ray shows sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle-not just simple periosteal elevation.

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D): Benign, locally aggressive tumor seen in skeletally mature individuals (usually after closure of epiphyses); rare in children and not associated with fever or signs of infection.

questions.text: In which of the following is the given position used?
questions.solution:
The sniffing position is primarily used during intubation to optimize alignment of the airway axes for better laryngoscopic view.

  • The sniffing position involves neck flexion with head extension, positioning the external auditory meatus in line with the sternal notch.
  • This posture aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, which enhances glottic visualization during direct laryngoscopy.
  • It is the standard positioning recommended for endotracheal intubation in most patients without suspected cervical spine injury.
  • The position improves the success rate of intubation and reduces the chances of airway trauma.

Explanation of other options:

Neurosurgery (Option A): Neurosurgical positioning depends on the site of the lesion-supine, prone, sitting, or lateral positions are commonly used. The sniffing position is not used.

NG tube insertion (Option C): Insertion of a nasogastric tube is usually done with the patient's head flexed forward, which helps guide the tube into the esophagus-not in the sniffing position.

Bougie insertion (Option D): A bougie is used as an aid during difficult intubation after sniffing position and failed visualization. The position itself is not specific to bougie use.

questions.text: Which drug is commonly used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence due to its ability to reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

  • Buprenorphine is widely used during the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal as part of Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST).
  • It is a partial opioid agonist with a ceiling effect, which lowers the risk of overdose while effectively reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
  • It is usually administered sublingually and can also be combined with naloxone to prevent misuse.
  • Buprenorphine is effective in stabilizing opioid-dependent patients and allowing them to maintain functional lives while gradually tapering off opioids.
  • Other agents used in OST include methadone (a full opioid agonist) and naltrexone (an antagonist).
  • However, buprenorphine is preferred for maintenance due to its safety profile and reduced abuse potential.

Explanation of other options:

Disulfiram (Option B): Used as an aversive agent in alcohol dependence, not effective in opioid withdrawal management.

Butorphanol (Option C): A mixed opioid agonist-antagonist used mainly for pain relief, not approved for maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder.

Clonidine (Option D): An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to alleviate acute withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, tremor, and sweating, but not effective as a long-term maintenance drug.

questions.text: The radiograph provided shows a lesion in the suprasellar region. Which type of visual field defect is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image demonstrates features of a craniopharyngioma, a tumour arising in the suprasellar region.

  • These lesions often exert pressure on the optic chiasm, particularly where the nasal retinal fibres from both eyes decussate.
  • Since these nasal fibres are responsible for detecting temporal visual fields, their compression leads to bitemporal hemianopia (a visual defect characterised by the loss of peripheral vision in both eyes).

Key Characteristics of Craniopharyngioma:

  • Originates from remnants of Rathke's pouch
  • Located above the sella turcica
  • Commonly presents in children (adamantinomatous type) or adults (papillary type)

Explanation for other options:

Altitudinal defect (Option A): Vision loss in either the upper or lower half of the visual field, often seen in ischemic optic neuropathy or retinal vascular occlusions, not due to optic chiasm compression.

Inferior arcuate scotoma (Option C): Characteristic of glaucoma, affecting the superior field due to damage along the arcuate nerve fibre path.

Bjerrum scotoma (Option D): Another type of paracentral scotoma seen in early glaucoma, follows the pattern of retinal nerve fibre loss and does not involve bilateral temporal field loss.

questions.text: What are the findings seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
Herbert pits are depressions or pits at the limbus, seen in trachoma. They result from the resolution of limbal follicles in chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Explanation for other options:

Horner-Trantas spots (Option A): These are white, chalky dots seen at the limbus in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic collections in an allergic response. They do not form pits but rather appear as elevated spots.

Pannus (Option C): Pannus is a subepithelial fibrovascular tissue growth over the cornea. Commonly seen in trachoma and contact lens-related hypoxia.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, inherited, progressive opacities affecting different corneal layers. Examples include Reis-Bücklers dystrophy (Bowman's layer) and Macular corneal dystrophy (stroma).

questions.text: What radiological sign is identifiable in the provided X-ray image?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray images (AP and lateral views) show a radiopaque foreign body in the upper oesophagus, with a characteristic double ring appearance. This finding is highly suggestive of an ingested button battery, a medical emergency requiring urgent removal.

  • The double ring sign is due to the two concentric metal components of the button battery:
    • Outer metal casing
    • Inner insulating ring
  • The lateral view helps distinguish between a coin (homogeneous opacity) and a button battery (double ring appearance).

Radiology of foreign bodies in trachea/ oesophagus:

Coin in the oesophagus is identified by a circular-shaped opacity seen on AP view and appears slit-like on lateral view.

Coin in trachea: Slit-like on AP view and Circular opacity on lateral view.

Button battery:

  • It can get dislodged in the oesophagus following accidental ingestion.
  • Peripheral double contour ring (or) Halo sign seen on X-ray distinguishes button battery from a coin in the oesophagus.

Explanation for other options:

Steeple Sign (Option A): It refers to the subglottic narrowing seen in croup on an AP neck X-ray.

String Sign (Option B): It refers to the narrowing of the terminal ileum in Crohn's disease, seen in contrast studies.

Thumb Sign (Option C): It refers to swelling of the epiglottis in epiglottitis, giving the appearance of a "thumb" on lateral neck X-ray.

Reference:

  1. Oesophagal foreign body - coin | Radiology Case | Radiopaedia.org
  2. Disk Battery Ingestion - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: On post-mortem, the dead body shows characteristic findings as depicted in the image. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Smothering involves obstruction of the nose and mouth, usually without specific injuries to the neck. Bruises or abrasions on the face may be present, but are not localised to the neck.

Explanation for other options:

Hanging (Option A): Hanging typically shows an oblique, non-continuous ligature mark on the neck, located higher up (above the thyroid cartilage). There is usually no evidence of external injuries like bruises or fingernail marks around the neck.

Throttling (Option B): Throttling refers to manual strangulation. The findings often include bruising, abrasions, or fingernail marks on the neck, which are characteristic of a physical struggle. There may also be petechial haemorrhages in the eyes and other areas due to venous congestion.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an SNRI antidepressant drug?
questions.solution:
Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and is used as an antidepressant. It affects norepinephrine reuptake exclusively and does not significantly impact serotonin levels.

Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs) primarily target the reuptake of norepinephrine, increasing its levels in the synaptic cleft. These drugs are commonly used in the treatment of conditions such as depression and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Some key SNRIs include:

  • Desipramine
  • Nortriptyline
  • Reboxetine

Explanation for other options:

Tramadol (Option B) is an analgesic with weak serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition properties. However, it is primarily used for pain management, and its SNRI-like effects are secondary, not its primary function. Therefore, it is not classified as an SNRI.

Paroxetine(Option C) is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It primarily inhibits serotonin reuptake and does not significantly affect norepinephrine, so it is not classified as an SNRI.

Bupropion (Option D) is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI), which primarily affects norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake. It does not significantly impact serotonin levels, so it is not considered an SNRI.

questions.text: A patient has a past history of infection with Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) O157:H7. What does the "H" represent?
questions.solution:
The "H" antigen in E. coli serotyping refers to the flagellar antigen, which determines the motility of the bacteria.

O157:H7 is a strain of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) known for producing Shiga toxin, leading to hemorrhagic colitis and Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS).

Serotyping of E. coli:

  • "O" antigen → Somatic (LPS) antigen (Option D)
  • "H" antigen → Flagellar antigen (Option C)
  • "K" antigen → Capsular antigen (Option A)

Fimbriae (Option B) aid in bacterial adhesion, but they are not part of E. coli serotyping as the "H" antigen.

questions.text: A man experiences sexual arousal from wearing female undergarments and high heels during sexual activity with women, but he is not attracted to men. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Transvestic Fetishism involves sexual arousal from wearing clothing of the opposite sex without a desire to change one's gender identity.

  • Transvestic Fetishism is classified under paraphilic disorders and is defined as sexual arousal obtained from cross-dressing, i.e., wearing clothes of the opposite sex.
  • It commonly occurs in heterosexual men, as in this case, where the man is not attracted to men but gets aroused by wearing female undergarments and high heels.
  • Importantly, there is no desire to transition genders, which distinguishes it from Gender Dysphoria.
  • The presence of this behavior in a sexual context, and not as a reflection of gender identity, confirms the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

Explanation of other options:

Gender Dysphoria (Option A): Involves psychological distress due to a mismatch between one's assigned gender at birth and experienced gender identity-not about sexual arousal from cross-dressing.

Hermaphroditism (Option C): Refers to an intersex condition involving both male and female genital characteristics; it is a biological disorder, not a psychiatric or behavioral one.

Gay Identity Disorder (Option D): Not a valid diagnostic term in current medical or psychiatric classifications. Moreover, the man is not attracted to men, so this is inapplicable.

questions.text:
Match the following ECG waves with the conditions:

a) Atrial flutter
b) Atrial fibrillation
c) Ventricular tachycardia
d) Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

1.
2.

3.

4.
questions.solution:
Atrial Flutter:

In atrial flutter, the standard PR interval is absent due to the presence of continuous, rapid flutter waves instead of discrete P waves. These flutter waves occur in a regular pattern at a rate of 250-350 beats per minute, producing the classic "sawtooth" appearance on ECG. Since the AV node conducts only a fraction of these impulses (commonly 2:1 or 4:1), the ventricular rhythm remains organized, but without a definable PR interval.

Atrial Fibrillation (AF):

The ECG in AF displays an irregularly irregular rhythm with normal QRS complexes. P waves are absent, and the baseline shows erratic, low-amplitude fibrillatory waves. The ventricular rate is typically rapid at onset (120-160 beats/min), but may become slower in chronic cases due to AV nodal fatigue or medication effects.

Ventricular Tachycardia (VT):

In monomorphic VT, the ECG shows wide QRS complexes (>120 ms) with a regular rhythm and uniform morphology across leads. The QRS axis varies based on the site of origin and may resemble either left or right bundle branch block patterns. In polymorphic VT, such as Torsades de Pointes, the QRS morphology changes continuously and is often linked to a prolonged QT interval.

Paroxysmal Ventricular Tachycardia:

This arrhythmia presents on ECG as a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia with QRS duration less than 120 ms and shortened R-R intervals. The heart rate typically ranges between 150-250 beats per minute. P waves are frequently absent or hidden within the T waves.

choices.text: Urine output of less than 60 ml in 4 hours

questions.text: A woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with a heart rate of 120 bpm and blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg. She has pedal edema and proteinuria and is diagnosed with eclampsia. She is started on the Pritchard regimen with magnesium sulfate. Under which of the following conditions should the treatment be stopped?
questions.solution:
Urine output less than 30 ml/hour (i.e., <60 ml in 4 hours) indicates possible magnesium accumulation and impending toxicity, necessitating cessation of magnesium sulfate.

  • Magnesium sulfate is the first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in eclampsia.
  • The Pritchard regimen involves a loading dose of 4 g IV and 10 g IM (5 g in each buttock), followed by a maintenance dose of 5 g IM every 4 hours in alternate buttocks.
  • Before giving each dose, three parameters must be confirmed:
    • Respiratory rate ≥ 16/min
    • Patellar reflexes present
    • Urine output ≥ 30 ml/hr
  • If urine output is <60 ml in 4 hours, magnesium excretion is reduced, increasing the risk of toxicity (due to renal clearance dependency).
  • In such cases, withholding the next dose and close monitoring is essential.
  • If signs of toxicity appear (respiratory depression, areflexia), 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate IV is the antidote.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory rate (RR) < 18 breaths per minute (Option A): While a low RR (<12/min) is a classic sign of toxicity, 18/min is not a cutoff to stop the drug. A RR <16/min should raise concern, but <12/min mandates immediate discontinuation and treatment.

Visual disturbances start (Option B): This is a feature of worsening preeclampsia or impending eclampsia, not magnesium toxicity. It is not an indication to stop magnesium sulfate.

Knee jerk reflex is present (Option C): Presence of patellar reflex is reassuring and required before giving each dose. Loss of reflex would indicate magnesium toxicity and is a contraindication to further dosing.

Reference:

https://www.bioline.org.br/pdf?am09018page 78

questions.text: What structure is marked "X" in the image provided below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked "X" is the testicular vein, which courses along the posterior abdominal wall toward the deep inguinal ring.

  • The testicular vein is part of the spermatic cord and drains blood from the testis via the pampiniform plexus.
  • It ascends in the retroperitoneum, with the right testicular vein draining into the IVC, and the left testicular vein draining into the left renal vein.
  • In surgical anatomy, this structure is identified near the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels and anterior to the psoas major.
  • It is especially important in inguinal hernia repair, orchidectomy, and varicocele surgery.

Basic Surgical Anatomy of the Testis:

Location and Structure

Paired oval-shaped organs in the scrotum.

Suspended by the spermatic cord (contains blood vessels, nerves, vas deferens).

Layers:

  • Tunica Vaginalis: Double-layered serous membrane from the peritoneum.
  • Tunica Albuginea: Dense, fibrous capsule beneath the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient with more than 104 colonies of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus in Urine Culture. What is the expected course of action?
questions.solution:
The presence of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) in significant numbers (>10ˆ4 colonies) suggests a urinary tract infection.

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)

Etiology and Prevalence:

  • Primary Cause: Colonic bacteria ascending the urinary tract.
  • Common Pathogen: Escherichia coli (54-67% of cases).
  • Other Pathogens: Klebsiella spp., Proteus spp., Enterococcus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Clinical Features and Classification:

  • Pyelonephritis (Kidney Infection): Upper renal collecting system involved
    • Symptoms: Abdominal/back/flank pain, fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
    • Newborns: Non-specific symptoms like poor feeding, irritability, jaundice, weight loss.
  • Cystitis (Bladder Infection): Only bladder involved
    • Symptoms: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain, incontinence, malodorous urine.
    • Typically does not cause high fever or renal injury.

Risk Factors for Recurrent UTI:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)
  • Bladder-Bowel Dysfunction (BBD)
  • Obstructive Uropathy
  • Urinary Tract Abnormalities: Anatomical issues like labial adhesion.
  • Neuropathic Bladder
  • Catheterisation: Procedures introducing bacteria.
  • Sexual Activity: Increases UTI risk in females.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine Culture: Gold standard for UTI diagnosis; identifies and quantifies bacteria.

Interpretation:

A colony count of >50,000 colony-forming units/mL of a single pathogen, along with pyuria or bacteriuria in a symptomatic child, is generally considered diagnostic of a UTI.

  • Urinalysis: Leukocyte Esterase and Nitrites positive.

Imaging Studies:

Treatment:

  • Antibiotic Therapy: Mainstay of UTI treatment.

Explanation for other options:

Take three urine samples (Option B) Multiple urine samples are needed for bloodstream infections (bacteremia), not for UTIs.

No treatment is needed (Option C) A colony count ≥104 CFU/mL in a symptomatic patient requires treatment.

Contaminated sample (Option D) S. saprophyticus is a known UTI pathogen, not a contaminant like other CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis).

questions.text: Following gastrectomy procedure which vitamin is to be supplemented for the patient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 deficiency can occur following gastrectomy due to intrinsic factor deficiency; thus, Vitamin B12 supplementation is done following gastrectomy.

Factors Affecting Vitamin B12 Absorption:

  1. Intrinsic Factor
    • A glycoprotein secreted by the gastric mucosa parietal cells.
    • It binds selectively to active forms of vitamin B12, which is essential for its absorption.
    • Deficiency occurs in patients who have undergone gastrectomy.
  2. Gastric Acidity and Enzymes: Adequate gastric acid and pepsin release vitamin B12 from its protein-bound form in food, making it available for cyclophilin.
  3. Cobalophilin:
    • A binding protein in saliva that initially binds vitamin B12 in the duodenum.
    • It is hydrolysed to release vitamin B12 for intrinsic factor binding.
  4. Pancreatic Sufficiency:
    • The pancreas aids digestion and absorption, possibly through cobalophilin hydrolysis.
  5. Ileal Receptors: Specialised receptors in the distal ileum recognise and bind the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex for absorption.

Explanation for other options:

Vitamin A (Option A) is primarily absorbed in the small intestine, not the stomach, and its absorption is usually unaffected by gastrectomy. Deficiency is more commonly associated with fat malabsorption (e.g., biliary disease or pancreatic insufficiency) rather than loss of gastric function.

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option B) deficiency is associated with chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, or prolonged vomiting (e.g., hyperemesis gravidarum). Although gastrectomy may reduce dietary intake, thiamine absorption occurs in the small intestine, so deficiency is less likely unless there is concurrent malnutrition.

Vitamin C (Option C) absorption occurs in the small intestine, and its deficiency is rare in gastrectomy patients unless there is severe dietary insufficiency. It is not directly affected by gastric acid or intrinsic factors.

questions.text: A patient presents with dermatitis, dementia, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The Clinical scenario of Dermatitis, Dementia and Cognitive decline suggests Niacin deficiency (Pellagra)

Pellagra is characterised by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
  • Bright red erythema in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
  • Casal's necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck (image)
  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia.

Explanation for other options:

Thiamine (Option B) (Vitamin B1) deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Tryptophan (Option C) plays a crucial role in various metabolic processes. It serves as a precursor for Niacin (Vitamin B3) and Serotonin. Thus, symptoms like mood alteration, decreased/increased appetite are also present.

Riboflavin (Option D) deficiency causes cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis and proliferation of bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

Key Takeaway:

Signs and symptoms of Pellagra:

  • Dermatitis
  • Diarrhoea
  • Dementia
  • Delirium
  • Depression
  • Death

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum-based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
  • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
    1. Vitamin B6 Deficiency
    2. Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
    3. Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
    4. Genetic Disorders: Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome - Excessive tryptophan is utilised for serotonin synthesis, causing niacin deficiency
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    1. Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    2. Malabsorption Syndromes

questions.solution: Each mechanoreceptor has a distinct function based on its structure and location in the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
Bochdalek hernia, a posterolateral diaphragmatic defect, is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), typically occurring on the left side.

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a developmental defect of the diaphragm that allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development (pulmonary hypoplasia).
  • Bochdalek Hernia -Key Features:
    • Location: Posterolateral diaphragm (usually left-sided)
    • Cause: Failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure during embryogenesis
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • Respiratory distress in the neonatal period
      • Scaphoid abdomen (due to displaced abdominal contents)
      • Decreased breath sounds on the affected side
      • Mediastinal shift on imaging
    • Diagnosis: Antenatal ultrasound or postnatal chest X-ray
    • Management: Initial stabilization with ventilation, followed by surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Hiatal Hernia (Option A): Involves stomach herniation through the esophageal hiatus. Typically acquired in adults, not a common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Morgagni Hernia (Option B): Anterior diaphragmatic defect through the foramen of Morgagni. It is less common and often asymptomatic or incidentally found.

Umbilical Hernia (Option D): Protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring, common in infants, but not a type of diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient undergoing orthopedic surgery under general anaesthesia suddenly developed a rise in EtCO2, temperature, and also muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs leads to such complications?
questions.solution:
Halothane is a triggering agent for malignant hyperthermia, presenting with hypercarbia, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity during anesthesia.

  • The clinical picture describes malignant hyperthermia (MH)-a rare, life-threatening hypermetabolic reaction to certain volatile anesthetics (like halothane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (like succinylcholine).
  • It is caused by a genetic mutation in the RYR1 gene, which leads to uncontrolled calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscles.
  • This results in sustained muscle contraction, rapid rise in EtCO2, hyperthermia, tachycardia, acidosis, and rhabdomyolysis.
  • Halothane, a volatile anesthetic, is a well-known trigger.
  • The treatment of choice is IV dantrolene, which blocks calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Explanation of other options:

Propofol (Option A): An intravenous induction agent; not associated with malignant hyperthermia.

Nitrous oxide (Option B): A non-triggering inhalational agent; does not cause MH.

Etomidate (Option C): An IV anesthetic used for induction; it is safe in MH-susceptible individuals.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle during a football match. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in inversion ankle sprains due to its anatomical location and relative weakness among lateral ligaments.

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is part of the lateral ligament complex of the ankle, which also includes the calcaneofibular and posterior talofibular ligaments.
  • It extends from the anterior margin of the lateral malleolus (fibula) to the neck of the talus.
  • During an inversion injury, the foot rolls inward, placing excessive strain on the lateral side of the ankle-especially the ATFL.
  • This ligament is most commonly injured in low ankle sprains, particularly during sports or missteps.
  • Injury Grading:
    • Grade I: Mild stretching
    • Grade II: Partial tear
    • Grade III: Complete rupture
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain and swelling over the lateral malleolus
    • Positive anterior drawer test
    • Bruising, tenderness, and instability of the ankle joint
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination (anterior drawer test)
    • X-rays to rule out fracture
    • MRI for soft tissue injury assessment
  • Treatment:
    • Grades I & II: RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), bracing, physiotherapy
    • Grade III: May require surgical repair

Explanation of other options:

Tibialis anterior tendon (Option A): Primarily involved in dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot; not typically injured in lateral (inversion) sprains as it lies anterior-medially.

Tibialis posterior tendon (Option B): Supports the medial longitudinal arch and assists in inversion; more commonly injured in medial ankle injuries or overuse, not lateral inversion sprains.

Extensor hallucis longus tendon (Option C): Involved in extension of the big toe and dorsiflexion; lies on the anterior ankle and is not subjected to strain during inversion.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459212/

questions.text: Injury to which cranial nerve causes an absent gag reflex?
questions.solution:
Damage to either CN IX or CN X can lead to an absent gag reflex, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) and an increased risk of aspiration.

The gag reflex (pharyngeal reflex) involves both the afferent and efferent limbs controlled by cranial nerves:

Cranial Nerves and Reflexes

Cranial nerves (CN) play a crucial role in reflexes by acting as afferent (sensory) or efferent (motor) pathways. Below is a summary of important cranial nerve-mediated reflexes:


Explanation for other options:

Cranial nerves X and VII (Option B): CN VII (Facial nerve) is involved in facial expression, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves VII and V (Option C): CN V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves V and IX (Option D): CN V is not involved in the motor response of the gag reflex.

choices.text: Expansion of right somatosensory fibres for the hand into neighbouring areas
Neighbouring fibres of the right somatosensory area extending into the right-hand area
Expansion of the right sensory cortex
Expansion of the left sensory cortex

questions.text: A patient experiences phantom limb pain following the amputation of the right limb. What would a PET scan most likely show in this condition?
questions.solution:
After amputation, the brain undergoes cortical reorganisation.

  • In this case, the neighbouring somatosensory fibres that previously represented adjacent body parts extend into the region that formerly represented the right hand.
  • This reorganisation is associated with the perception of phantom limb pain.

Expansion of right somatosensory fibres for the hand into neighbouring areas (Option A):

  • Somatosensory fibres specifically responsible for the right hand expand into neighbouring regions.
  • However, it is not the fibres themselves that expand; rather, it is the cortical representation that changes.

Expansion of right sensory cortex (Option C):

  • Implies a general enlargement of the right sensory cortex.
  • However, the expansion is not global; rather, it involves the neighbouring cortical areas invading the region corresponding to the amputated limb.

Expansion of left sensory cortex (Option D):

  • The left sensory cortex is responsible for processing sensory input from the right side of the body.
  • The reorganisation occurs in the sensory cortex corresponding to the amputated limb (in this case, the right cortex, which processes left-sided sensations).

Learning objective:

Phantom Limb Pain

  • Perceived due to cortical plasticity
  • In the phantom limb phenomenon, the limb does not exist (amputated), but the patient complains that he feels pain or itch in the limb.
  • Based on the evidence, brain reorganisation occurs when sensory input is cut off. For example, in leg amputees, the ventral posterior thalamic nucleus can perceive the signal that once received feedback from the leg and foot, now responds to stump (thigh) stimulation.

Management :

  1. Epidural Anaesthesia: Used during amputation surgery to reduce acute pain and subsequent need for opioids, lowering phantom pain incidence.
  2. Spinal Cord Stimulation: Electric current stimulates spinal pathways, reducing phantom limb pain and causing a tingling sensation insteadin the phantom limb

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, and serum triglyceride levels are 1500 mg/dL. What is the most likely underlying defect?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of severe abdominal pain and elevated serum triglyceride levels suggests familial chylomicronaemia syndrome, and it is caused by an Apo-CII defect.

Explanation for other options:

Apo B-48 defect (Option A) is commonly associated with abetalipoproteinemia. Clinical features include fat malabsorption, Vitamin K deficiency, and Vitamin A deficiency symptoms.

Apo B-100 defect (Option B) (Hypercholesterolemia)presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

LDL receptor defect (Option D)(Hypercholesterolemia)presents with atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease (early onset) and Tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: A man presents with back pain following a road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X-ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The absence of neurological deficits and X-ray findings of isolated posterior element involvement point to a spinous process fracture.

  • Spinous process fractures occur due to direct trauma or hyperextension injuries and involve the posterior bony projection of a vertebra.
  • These fractures are often stable, and because the spinal canal and neural structures remain unaffected, there are usually no neurological deficits.
  • X-ray typically shows a clear fracture line through the spinous process without vertebral body collapse or disruption of alignment.
  • In the context of trauma with localized pain and preserved neurologic function, this diagnosis is most consistent.

Explanation of other options:

Chance fracture (Option B): Horizontal fracture through the vertebra due to flexion-distraction injuries (e.g., seatbelt injury). Often involves the vertebral body and posterior elements, more severe, and commonly associated with neurological deficits.

Fracture of base of vertebrae (Option C): Refers to more generalized vertebral body fractures (e.g., endplate or pedicle); may involve instability or neurological compromise, not limited to the spinous process.

Compressed fracture (Option D): Involves anterior wedging or collapse of the vertebral body, often due to axial loading; may present with vertebral body height loss on imaging-not consistent with isolated spinous process injury.

Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S073646791630021X

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with a lesion as shown below. This would cause what kind of field abnormality?
questions.solution:
Bitemporal hemianopia occurs due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, where nasal fibres from both eyes cross. Since these fibres are responsible for the temporal visual fields, their damage leads to loss of vision in the outer halves of both visual fields.

  • Common causes: Pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma, or meningioma compressing the optic chiasm.

Explanation for other options:

Homonymous hemianopia (Option A): This results from a lesion posterior to the optic chiasm (e.g., in the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, or occipital lobe).

Complete blindness (Option C): Total blindness occurs due to a lesion before the optic chiasm affecting the optic nerve of one eye.

Single vision field loss (Option D): This occurs with a lesion affecting only one optic nerve, not the chiasm.

questions.text: What is the term for the interval between the entry of a pathogen into the host and the point at which the host reaches peak infectivity?
questions.solution:
Generation time refers to the interval of time between the recieving of the infection by the host and the maximal infectivity of that host. It encompasses the entire cycle of infection, transmission, and symptom onset in the context of disease spread.

Incubation Period:

  • The incubation period refers to the time it takes for an individual to develop symptoms after being infected with a pathogen.
  • It begins with exposure to the pathogen and ends with the appearance of recognisable symptoms.

Window Period: (Option C ruled out)

  • The window period is the time between infection and when the infection can be reliably detected by diagnostic tests.
  • The individual may be infectious during this period, but tests might not yet show positive results.
  • This concept is important in screening and testing strategies for infectious diseases.

Median incubation period: (Option B ruled out)

  • The median incubation period is the time for 50% of cases to show symptoms after exposure.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of foul-smelling sputum, fever, and shortness of breath. Based on the chest X-ray shown below, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray reveals a cavity with a distinct air-fluid level, which, in the context of clinical symptoms such as fetid sputum, dyspnea, and fever, is strongly suggestive of a lung abscess.

A lung abscess is a localised collection of pus within the lung parenchyma, often resulting from aspiration pneumonia, necrotising infections, or septic emboli. The foul odour of sputum points toward anaerobic bacterial infection, a classic feature of lung abscesses.

Explanation for other options:

Pneumothorax (Option B): Would typically show a lucent (dark) area without vascular markings peripheral to the collapsed lung margin. The image and symptoms here suggest fluid and cavity, not air alone.

Pleural effusion (Option C): Often seen as blunting of the costophrenic angles or a homogenous opacity in the dependent portion of the thorax. Air-fluid level in the lung parenchyma is not a feature.

Pericardial effusion (Option D): Presents with a globular or "water bottle" appearance of the cardiac silhouette. It does not cause cavitation or air-fluid levels in the lung fields.

References:

  1. NCBI: Lung Abscess
  2. Radiopaedia: Lung Abscess

questions.text: A patient undergoing the Worth 4 Dot Test reports seeing only three green dots. What does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
If the patient only sees three green dots, it suggests suppression of the right eye, as the red lens over the right eye would normally allow them to see the red dot. The fact that only green dots are seen indicates that the right eye is not contributing to vision.

Worth's Four Dot Test

The patient wears goggles with red lenses in front of the right eye and green lenses in front of the left eye and views a box with 4 lights - one red, two green and one white.

Results are interpreted as below:

  • Normal binocular single vision: Patient sees all four lights in the absence of manifest squint (image A).
  • Abnormal retinal correspondence: Patient sees all four lights even in the presence of a manifest squint.
  • Left eye suppression (Option B): Patient sees only two red lights (image B).
  • Right eye suppression (Option A): Patient sees only three green lights (image C).
  • Alternating suppression: The Patient sees three green lights and two red lights, alternately.
  • Diplopia (Option C and D): Patient sees 5 lights (2 red and 3 green) (image D & E).
    • Crossed diplopia (exotropia) → Red dots seen on the left
    • Uncrossed diplopia (esotropia) → Red dots seen on the right

questions.text: Obstruction of which sinus drainage is seen in the image provided?
questions.solution:
The image appears to show a nasal endoscopy view of inflamed and polypoidal mucosa obstructing the middle meatus, which is the drainage site of the maxillary sinus.

The maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus via the ostiomeatal complex (OMC), which includes the hiatus semilunaris and infundibulum. Any obstruction in this pathway leads to maxillary sinusitis, commonly seen with nasal polyps.

The maxillary sinus:

The maxillary sinus, or the Antrum of Highmore, is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla.

  • Shape - Pyramidal
  • Size - 15mL
  • Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose
  • Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone

Relations:

  • Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla.
  • Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meati and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity.
  • Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit
  • Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oroantral fistula.
  • Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery.
  • Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein.
  • Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes.
  • Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2).

Explanation for other options:

Ethmoid Sinus (Option B): The ethmoid sinuses primarily drain into the middle and superior meatus, and their obstruction is associated with frontal or sphenoethmoidal recess involvement.

Sphenoid Sinus (Option C): It drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, located superiorly, which is not prominently obstructed in this image.

Frontal Sinus (Option D): It drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, and its obstruction is more commonly associated with frontal headaches and pain above the eyes.

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post-fertilisation?
questions.solution:
Implantation begins around Day 5 post-fertilisation when the blastocyst reaches the uterus and starts attaching to the endometrial lining. The process continues over the next few days, with full implantation completed by Day 9-10.


Reference:

  1. First week of development

questions.text: A young athlete presented with chest pain and dyspnea. His brother passed away due to sudden cardiac death. He is diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). A harsh systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Which of the following maneuvers will increase the intensity of this murmur?
questions.solution:
The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload, exacerbating left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) in HCM and thereby increasing the murmur.

  • This is a classic case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM), an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO), and increased risk of sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes.
  • Genetic mutations:
    • β-myosin heavy chain: Associated with significant hypertrophy and earlier presentation.
    • Troponin T: May cause minimal hypertrophy but high risk of sudden cardiac death due to myocardial disarray.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The thickened septum narrows the LVOT.
    • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve further blocks the outflow.
    • LV becomes non-compliant, impairing diastolic filling.
    • Myocyte disarray increases risk of arrhythmias, especially ventricular fibrillation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Exertional angina, dyspnea, and syncope due to dynamic obstruction and poor diastolic filling.
    • Sudden cardiac death often during exertion, especially in genetically predisposed athletes.
    • Jerky or bifid pulse due to dynamic changes in LV ejection.
    • Harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border, which mimics aortic stenosis but lacks radiation to the neck.
  • Why murmur increases with Valsalva:
    • The Valsalva maneuver reduces venous return and preload, leading to a smaller LV cavity. This enhances septal-mitral valve contact, worsening the dynamic LVOT obstruction and increasing the intensity of the murmur in HOCM.

Explanation of other options:

Squatting (Option A): Increases both venous return and afterload, which distends the LV cavity and relieves the obstruction, thereby reducing murmur intensity.

Leaning forward with head down/up (Option B): This maneuver accentuates diastolic murmurs, particularly of aortic regurgitation, but has no significant impact on HOCM murmur.

Hand grip (Option C): Increases afterload, which reduces the gradient across the obstructed LVOT and diminishes murmur intensity in HCM.

Reference: https://litfl.com/hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy-hcm-ecg-library/

https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article-abstract/37/5/498/2466086?redirectedFrom=fulltext

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1168371/

https://www.healio.com/cardiology/learn-the-heart/cardiology-review/topic-reviews/s2-heart-sound#

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.text: A female presents with 22 weeks of pregnancy as a result of sexual assault. Which statement is true regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape/sexual assault, with the opinion of two doctors.


Explanation for other options:

Timing for MTP:

  • Up to 20 weeks: One doctor's opinion is required.
  • Beyond 20 weeks and less than 24 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman's life and pregnancy caused due to rape (Two doctors' decision). (Option C)
  • Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life.
  • Beyond 24 weeks: It is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board. (Option D ruled out)

Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor's opinion is required (Option A): Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother (Option B): While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

Reference: Legal Abortion Limit Raised up to 24 Weeks of Gestation for Substantial Foetal Anomalies or for Rape Victims: a Welcome Step for Women and Health Providers in India - PMC

questions.text: The MRCP image shown below demonstrates findings consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A choledochal cyst refers to a congenital dilation of parts of the biliary tree, most often the common bile duct (CBD). Though commonly diagnosed in children, it may also be discovered in adulthood. The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image in this case likely reveals a fusiform or saccular dilation of the CBD, a hallmark feature of a choledochal cyst.

Common Clinical Manifestations:

  • Recurrent episodes of right upper abdominal pain
  • Jaundice, due to biliary stasis or obstruction
  • Occasionally, a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant
  • Increased lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

Explanation for other options:

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option B): Presents as an irregular stricture or mass in the biliary tract, not as a smooth, cystic enlargement of the duct.

Cholelithiasis (Option C): Involves gallstones within the gallbladder, with no associated dilation of the CBD. MRCP may show shadowing or echogenic foci in the gallbladder.

Choledocholithiasis (Option D): Refers to the presence of stones within the CBD. MRCP shows filling defects within the duct rather than generalised dilation.

Reference: NCBI Book: Choledochal Cyst

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with fever, purpuric rash over the thigh, and migratory swelling of the right knee and left ankle joints. On cardiac auscultation, a soft diastolic murmur is noted at the apex. Laboratory tests reveal negative rheumatoid factors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, migratory polyarthritis, a diastolic murmur, and seronegativity strongly suggest acute rheumatic fever.

  • The clinical scenario presents hallmark features of acute rheumatic fever (ARF)-a febrile illness following group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) pharyngitis, with major manifestations including migratory arthritis, carditis, and skin findings.
  • The Jones Criteria guide the diagnosis, and this patient demonstrates:
    • Migratory arthritis involving large joints (right knee and left ankle)
    • Carditis, as evidenced by the diastolic apical murmur, likely a Carey Coombs murmur due to early mitral valvulitis
    • A history of fever
    • Seronegativity for rheumatoid factor, ruling out autoimmune arthritides
  • ARF typically manifests 2-3 weeks post-streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • The polyarthritis is often migratory and transient.
  • Carditis may involve the mitral and/or aortic valves, initially causing regurgitation, with a risk of progression to chronic rheumatic heart disease.
  • The Carey Coombs murmur, a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, is specific to ARF and reflects inflammatory thickening of the mitral valve leaflets, not stenosis or regurgitation per se.
  • Other late features include chorea, subcutaneous nodules, and erythema marginatum, though they are less common.


Explanation of other options:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Option B): Typically presents with chronic joint swelling and stiffness, especially in the morning. Systemic JIA may cause fever, but diastolic murmur and migratory arthritis are not characteristic.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): A chronic autoimmune condition affecting adults with symmetric polyarthritis and usually positive rheumatoid factor. The acute presentation and seronegativity make this diagnosis unlikely.

Seronegative arthropathy (Option D): Encompasses conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, and psoriatic arthritis, which usually involve axial skeleton or entheses, often chronic and without a diastolic murmur or acute febrile course.

questions.text: Which area is affected by the fracture shown in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a fracture at the tibial tuberosity, the site of patellar tendon insertion.

  • A tibial tuberosity fracture involves the anterior projection of the proximal tibia where the patellar tendon inserts.
  • It is commonly seen in adolescent males during growth spurts, often following sudden quadriceps contraction, especially during jumping sports.
  • The fracture typically presents with pain, swelling, and inability to extend the knee, and X-ray reveals a fracture at the tibial tuberosity.
  • While Osgood-Schlatter disease affects the same region, it is a chronic overuse condition, not an acute fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Medial epicondyle of tibia (Option B): This is not a commonly fractured area and lies medially near the tibial plateau; its fracture would not correspond with the tibial tuberosity seen on X-ray.

Gerdy's tubercle fracture (Option C): Located laterally on the proximal tibia as the attachment site of the iliotibial band; fractures here are rare and appear on the lateral side of the tibia, not anteriorly.

Osgood-Schlatter disease (Option D): This is a traction apophysitis, not a true fracture, seen in adolescents with chronic anterior knee pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity, but without acute disruption of bone continuity as in a fracture.

choices.text: Conscious patient with pulse & breathing present
Unconscious patient with pulse & breathing present
Unconscious patient with pulse present but no breathing
Unconscious patient without pulse but breathing present

questions.text: When do you put a victim in the following position?
questions.solution:
The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient with intact pulse and breathing to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

  • The recovery position is indicated for patients who are unconscious but have spontaneous breathing and a palpable pulse.
  • This position involves turning the person onto their side with the head tilted slightly back to maintain airway openness and promote drainage of secretions (like vomit or saliva), thereby preventing aspiration and airway obstruction.
  • It is a first-aid measure used while waiting for medical help to arrive, especially when there's no indication for CPR.

Explanation of other options:

Conscious patient with pulse & breathing present (Option A): Recovery position is not needed as the patient is alert and can maintain their airway independently.

Unconscious patient with pulse present but no breathing (Option C): This is a case of respiratory arrest-rescue breathing or ventilation support is required, not the recovery position.

Unconscious patient without pulse but breathing present (Option D): This scenario is not physiologically possible, as lack of pulse implies cardiac arrest, and spontaneous breathing would not occur-CPR is indicated, not the recovery position.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis with a high anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of salicylic acid tablets.

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals:
pH = 7.30
pCO₂ = 16 mmHg
HCO₃⁻ = 6.3 mmol/L
Na⁺ = 135 mmol/L
K⁺ = 4.5 mmol/L
Cl⁻ = 113.7 mmol/L
Lactate = Normal

Which of the following best describes the acid-base abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's ABG shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with evidence of partial respiratory alkalosis, commonly seen in salicylate poisoning.

  • This question revolves around interpreting an ABG in the context of salicylate poisoning, which characteristically causes a mixed acid-base disorder.
  • Here's a stepwise interpretation:
    • Step 1: Check pH
      • pH = 7.30 → Indicates acidemia
    • Step 2: Identify the primary disorder
      • HCO₃⁻ = 6.3 mmol/L (Low) → Suggests primary metabolic acidosis
      • pCO₂ = 16 mmHg (Low) → Normally, this would compensate for metabolic acidosis, but the level is lower than expected, hinting at a respiratory alkalosis component as well.
    • Step 3: Calculate the anion gap
      • Anion gap = Na⁺ - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)
      • = 135 - (113.7 + 6.3) = 15 mEq/L
      • Normal AG = 6-12 mEq/L → Thus, elevated anion gap
    • Step 4: Assess respiratory compensation using Winter's formula
      • Expected pCO₂ = (1.5 x HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2 = (1.5 x 6.3) + 8 = 17.45 ± 2 → Range: 15.5-19.5 mmHg
      • Actual pCO₂ = 16 mmHg → Within range → Compensatory respiratory alkalosis
  • However, in salicylate poisoning, respiratory alkalosis may precede metabolic acidosis, creating a true mixed disorder.
  • So, the acid-base status is:
    • Primary high anion gap metabolic acidosis
    • With superimposed respiratory alkalosis → mixed picture
  • This pattern is characteristic of salicylate (aspirin) toxicity due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center and resulting hyperventilation.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis (Option B): Incorrect. The pCO₂ is low, not high, and HCO₃⁻ is also low, ruling out both respiratory acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.

Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis (Option C): Incorrect. The respiratory system has partially compensated for the metabolic acidosis, as pCO₂ is within the Winter's predicted range.

Respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect. This pattern would show high pCO₃ and high HCO₃⁻, opposite to the findings here.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has consulted multiple plastic surgeons to correct a perceived facial deformity. Despite reassurances from doctors and her family that no such defect exists, she remains convinced and frequently checks her appearance in the mirror. She insists on surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
SSRIs are first-line pharmacological treatment for Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), as they help reduce obsessional thoughts and compulsive behaviours related to perceived appearance flaws.

  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by:
    • Preoccupation with a perceived defect or flaw in appearance (often imagined or minor)
    • Repetitive behaviours such as mirror checking, excessive grooming, or seeking reassurance
    • Social withdrawal and impaired functioning
    • High rates of plastic surgery consultation, which often provides no relief
  • BDD falls under the Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders category in DSM-5.
  • Key Features:
    • Persistent thoughts about perceived physical flaws
    • Excessive comparisons with others
    • Poor insight or delusional conviction about their appearance
    • Functional impairment due to distress
  • Management:
    • First-line pharmacotherapy: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine)
    • First-line psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
    • Surgery is not recommended and usually leads to dissatisfaction

Explanation of other options:

Atypical antipsychotic (Option B): Used only in severe or delusional BDD or when there's poor response to SSRIs; not first-line.

Insight therapy (Option C): Insight-oriented psychotherapy is not effective in BDD, as most patients have poor or absent insight into their condition.

SNRI (Option D): SNRIs are less effective than SSRIs for obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders like BDD and are not first-line.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4948290/

questions.text: Which neonatal anomaly is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Exstrophy bladder is a congenital anomaly where the bladder mucosa is exposed outside the abdominal wall due to failure of mesodermal migration.

  • Bladder exstrophy results from a failure of mesoderm to migrate and form the lower abdominal wall, leading to a defect through which the posterior bladder wall protrudes and is visible externally.
  • It typically presents in neonates with the bladder mucosa exposed, downwardly displaced umbilicus, widely separated pubic symphysis, and epispadias.
  • In males, dorsal chordee and shortened penis are seen.
  • In females, there is bifid clitoris and wide labial separation.
  • If left untreated, patients suffer from complete urinary incontinence and are at increased risk for bladder adenocarcinoma.
  • This condition is easily distinguishable from other anterior abdominal wall defects due to visible bladder mucosa, absence of a herniated bowel sac, and association with genital anomalies.

Explanation of other options:

Omphalocele (Option A): Presents as herniation of abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a translucent sac. The umbilical cord inserts into the sac-not seen in exstrophy.

Gastroschisis (Option B): Abdominal wall defect lateral to the umbilicus, with free-floating bowel loops that lack a covering sac-distinct from bladder mucosa exposure.

Patent vitello intestinal duct (Option C): Persistent communication between the intestine and umbilicus, may present as a fistula, sinus, or cyst near the umbilicus-does not show an exposed bladder.

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.text: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. Ultrasonography reveals distention of the portal vein, and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been initiated. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
In acute upper GI bleeding, initial stabilization with IV fluids and electrolytes is the immediate priority before any definitive diagnostic or therapeutic procedures.

  • The patient is a chronic alcoholic presenting with hematemesis, likely due to ruptured esophageal varices secondary to portal hypertension.
  • Ultrasound findings of portal vein distention and hyperechoic liver suggest alcoholic liver disease with cirrhosis, predisposing him to variceal bleeding.
  • Initial management of any acute upper GI bleed follows the ABCs of resuscitation:
    • Airway protection
    • Breathing support
    • Circulatory stabilization - with IV fluids, blood products if necessary, and electrolyte correction
  • Only after stabilization, further steps like upper GI endoscopy to locate and treat bleeding varices are performed.
  • IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI) like pantoprazole help reduce gastric acid and stabilize clots in non-variceal bleeding.
  • In suspected variceal bleeding, drugs like octreotide or terlipressin are added.
  • So, the next most appropriate step after initiating PPI is IV fluid resuscitation.

Explanation of other options:

Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option A): While antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) are important in variceal bleeding to prevent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), they are started after hemodynamic stabilization, not immediately.

Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis (Option B): Liver biopsy is not indicated in the acute setting of a GI bleed. Diagnosis of cirrhosis can be made clinically and via imaging; biopsy is reserved for unclear cases in stable patients.

Perform an endoscopy to look for varices (Option D): Endoscopy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic tool, but only after the patient is hemodynamically stabilized with fluids and/or transfusions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic lower abdominal pain that worsens during menstruation. An ultrasound (USG) shows a cystic ovarian mass with a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Endometriomas are cystic ovarian lesions associated with endometriosis and show a characteristic "ground glass" appearance on ultrasound.

  • Endometriosis is a chronic gynecological condition where ectopic endometrial tissue is found outside the uterus, commonly on ovaries.
  • When endometriosis involves the ovaries, it leads to the formation of endometriomas-also called "chocolate cysts" due to the presence of altered blood.
  • Ultrasound (USG) findings show a cystic mass with homogeneous low-level internal echoes, termed a "ground glass" appearance.
  • This is typical of endometriomas and helps distinguish them from other adnexal masses.
  • Associated diagnostic points:
    • Laparoscopy is the investigation of choice.
    • Histopathology confirms the diagnosis, showing hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
    • MRI helps with better characterisation, showing hyperintense T1 and "shading" on T2.

Explanation of other options:

Intramural fibroid (Option A): Solid masses within the uterine wall; do not appear cystic or have ground glass appearance.

Adenomyoma (Option B): Appears as a heterogeneous mass in the myometrium, not as a cystic ovarian lesion.

Myomatous polyp (Option D): Pedunculated, solid uterine masses; not associated with ovarian cysts or ground glass appearance.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10120420/

questions.text: Paralysis of which muscle causes ptosis in Horner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is primarily due to the paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (also known as Müller's muscle).

  • This muscle is responsible for maintaining the eyelid position and lifting the upper eyelid slightly.
  • In Horner's syndrome, the sympathetic innervation to the superior tarsal muscle is disrupted, resulting in ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

Explanation for other options:

Orbitalis (Option B): The orbitalis muscle is not involved in ptosis. It helps in closing the eyelids but does not contribute to the sympathetic control of the eyelid.

Orbicularis oculi (Option C): This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid, but ptosis in Horner's syndrome is caused by a sympathetic defect affecting the superior tarsal muscle, not the orbicularis oculi.

Sphincter pupillae (Option D): The sphincter pupillae muscle is responsible for pupil constriction (miosis) under parasympathetic control, not related to ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: Which type of papillae on the tongue do not contain taste buds?
questions.solution:
Filiform papillae are the only type of tongue papillae that lack taste buds.

  • They are responsible for creating the rough texture on the tongue surface, which aids in food manipulation and the perception of food texture, not taste.

Explanation for other options:

Fungiform papillae (Option A): These are mushroom-shaped bumps on the tongue that contain taste buds and are sensitive to sweet, salty, sour, and umami flavours

Circumvallate papillae (Option C): These are large, dome-shaped structures located at the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement:

Foliate papillae (Option D): These are ridged structures on the sides of the tongue that contain taste buds and are particularly sensitive to sour flavours:



Key Takeaway:

Types of Papilla in Tongue:

questions.text: A 36-year-old fruit farmer presents with fever, breathing difficulties and neurological complications. He gives a history of spotting a few bats on his farm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus that fruit farmers are particularly at risk of contracting due to its association with fruit bats.

  • It presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Explanation for other options:

Ebola (Option A): Ebola virus primarily causes hemorrhagic fever with symptoms like severe bleeding, multi-organ failure, and shock. While it can present with fever and some neurological complications, respiratory symptoms are not typical, and there is no specific association with fruit farming.

Meningitis (Option B): It causes inflammation of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, leading to fever, headache, neck stiffness, and neurological complications. However, respiratory symptoms are uncommon, and the condition is not linked to fruit farming.

Zika (Option D): Zika virus primarily causes mild symptoms like fever, rash, and joint pain, and is more famous for its complications during pregnancy, such as microcephaly in newborns. It does not commonly cause severe respiratory or neurological issues, nor is it specifically associated with fruit farming.

Reference:

  1. Ebola Virus Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Nipah Virus - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual presents with sudden-onset epigastric pain and an elevated serum lipase level. He is stabilised after three days. Based on the chest X-ray provided, what is the most likely pulmonary complication?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are indicative of acute pancreatitis, a condition that can trigger systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). One of the major extra-abdominal complications of acute pancreatitis is ARDS, which arises due to increased pulmonary capillary permeability, leading to fluid accumulation in the alveolar spaces.

Key Radiographic Findings in ARDS:

  • Bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities
  • Typically without signs of cardiomegaly or pleural effusion
  • Indicative of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

Explanation for other options:

Acute Pulmonary Oedema (Option B): Usually cardiogenic in origin, often linked with left ventricular failure. It typically shows vascular redistribution, Kerley B lines, and cardiomegaly on imaging.

Pulmonary Thromboembolism (Option C): May not produce any visible findings on a chest X-ray. Diagnosis relies on CT pulmonary angiography or V/Q scanning.

Miliary Tuberculosis (Option D): Causes numerous tiny nodular opacities diffusely scattered throughout the lungs. Associated with chronic constitutional symptoms such as prolonged fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Reference: Acute lung injury and ARDS in acute pancreatitis: Mechanisms and potential intervention - PMC

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the ophthalmology outpatient department with the condition shown. What is the most appropriate course of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of Bilateral congenital cataracts. Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.


Explanation for other options:

Medical management (Option A):

  • Delaying surgery in cases of significant cataract can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) due to sensory deprivation.
  • Medical management is only supportive and not the primary treatment.

Surgery after 6 months (Option C): Delaying surgery for 6 months can lead to irreversible visual impairment due to deprivation amblyopia.

Surgery after 2 years (Option D): Waiting until 2 years would result in severe amblyopia, making visual rehabilitation nearly impossible.

questions.text: What is the gene commonly involved in carcinoma histology shown below?
questions.solution:
The histopathology shown in the image shows Orphan Annie's eye nucleus (seen in papillary thyroid cancer) associated with the BRAF V600 gene.

Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread.

  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion.
  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.
  • HPE shows
    • True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular cores.
    • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
    • Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
    • Presence of psammoma bodies - Dystrophic calcifications.


Explanation for other options:

RAS (Option A) mutations are commonly found in

  • Follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Follicular adenomas.
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Lung adenocarcinoma.

RET (Option B) mutation is seen in

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (as part of MEN2 syndromes)
  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (via RET/PTC rearrangements)

P53 (Option D) mutation is seen in Breast, lung, and colon carcinomas.

Learning Objective:

BRAF V600E mutation seen in:

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid
  • Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is associated with broad-based budding?
questions.solution:
Blastomyces is associated with broad-based budding.

Explanation for other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option A) appears as rosettes of conidia on microscopy.

Talaromyces marneffei (Option C) appear as brush/broom conidia on microscopy.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (Option D) is characterized by a "pilot's wheel" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance of the yeast form.

Reference:

  1. PAS and GMS utility in dermatopathology: Review of the current medical literature - Shalin - 2020 - Journal of Cutaneous Pathology - Wiley Online Library
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441987/

questions.solution:
For the treatment of mixed malaria infection with Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum, the treatment regimen typically includes artesunate for blood stages & P. falciparum and primaquine for liver stages & P. vivax.

questions.text: What are the sequential steps in rigour mortis?
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.

  • Order of Appearance:

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes

Rigor mortis

Rigor mortis (RM), or cadaveric rigidity, refers to the stiffening of muscles after death, resulting from biochemical changes within muscle cells due to ATP depletion.

Progression of Rigor Mortis:

The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases.

Rules of Progression

1. Nysten's Rule

Rigour mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.

  • Order of Appearance:

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes

  • Order of Disappearance:
