Fingers and toes → Lower limbs → Abdomen → Upper limbs → Muscles of chest → Muscles of face → Lower jaw → Neck → Eyelid muscles → Myocardium

2. Shapiro's RuleRigor mortis is a biochemical process that occurs simultaneously across all muscles, with visibility depending on muscle bulk.

3. Rule of 12

Onset occurs at 60 minutes, peaks at 12 hours, remains for another 12 hours, and resolves completely thereafter.

choices.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 1 (VDDR type 1)
Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 2 (VDDR type 2)

questions.text: A child presents with bone deformities. Lab findings show normal serum calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterised by low phosphate levels, normal calcium and PTH, and elevated ALP, leading to bone deformities.

Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause renal osteodystrophy, which may lead to pathological fractures.

Key Takeaway:

Vitamin D deficiency presents with:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Elevated parathyroid hormone
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase
  • Decreased 25-hydroxy vitamin D

questions.text: A patient presents with a headache, recurrent episodes of high blood pressure, and tachycardia. Her urine shows elevated levels of vanillylmandelic acid, and a CT scan reveals a retroperitoneal tumour in the right lumbar region. Which of the following syndromes is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN 2A, VHL, HPPS, and NF1, but not with NF2, which primarily involves schwannomas and meningiomas.

  • This patient has classic features of pheochromocytoma:
    • Symptoms: Headache, hypertension, tachycardia, sweating
    • Biochemical marker: Elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), a catecholamine metabolite
    • Imaging: Retroperitoneal tumor, possibly adrenal or extra-adrenal (paraganglioma)
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare catecholamine-secreting tumors derived from chromaffin cells, usually located in the adrenal medulla.
  • They may also arise from extra-adrenal paraganglia (called paragangliomas).

Syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma:

  • MEN 2A and 2B (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia):
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia (in MEN 2A)
  • Von Hippel-Lindau Disease (VHL):
    • Hemangioblastomas, retinal angiomas, RCC, pancreatic cysts, and pheochromocytoma
  • Hereditary:
    • Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (HPPS):
    • Caused by mutations in SDH genes (e.g., SDHB, SDHD)
    • Associated with head, neck, thoracic, or abdominal paragangliomas
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) (not listed in the question):
    • Café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, optic gliomas, and pheochromocytoma

Explanation of other options:

MEN 2A syndrome (Option A): Associated with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

Von Hippel-Lindau Disease (Option B): Autosomal dominant syndrome strongly linked with pheochromocytomas and other vascular tumors.

Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (Option D): These are the classic familial syndromes associated with pheochromocytomas or extra-adrenal paragangliomas.

Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (Option C): NF2 involves bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas, not typically associated with pheochromocytomas. This distinguishes it from NF1, which is associated with pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: A sexually active woman presents with foul-smelling, watery vaginal discharge. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis infection typically causes foul-smelling, thin, watery vaginal discharge, often accompanied by vulvar irritation and itching.

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • It is one of the most common causes of malodorous, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge in women.
  • Key clinical features include:
    • Thin, foul-smelling, watery or frothy discharge
    • Strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages on cervix)
    • Vaginal pruritus and irritation
    • Dyspareunia and dysuria may also be present
  • Diagnosis:
    • Wet mount microscopy: Motile, flagellated protozoa
    • NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test) is highly sensitive
    • Vaginal pH typically > 4.5
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole (2g single dose or 500 mg BID x 7 days)
    • Treat sexual partners simultaneously to prevent reinfection

Explanation of other options:

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option A): Causes bacterial vaginosis, which presents with thin, grey-white discharge with fishy odor (especially after intercourse). Discharge is usually not watery or frothy, and clue cells are seen on microscopy.

Candida albicans (Option B): Causes thick, white, curd-like (cottage cheese) discharge, with intense itching. The discharge is typically odorless, not foul-smelling.

Lactobacillus (Option D): This is part of the normal vaginal flora and plays a protective role by maintaining acidic pH. It is not a pathogen.

questions.text: An infant presents with recurrent chest infections and tachypnea. Identify the likely clinical condition.
questions.solution:
CCAM presents in infancy with recurrent respiratory infections and tachypnea due to malformed cystic lung tissue.

  • Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (CCAM), now known as Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM), is a rare developmental malformation where hamartomatous lung tissue forms cysts, typically limited to a single lobe.
  • These cysts impair normal lung function, leading to symptoms such as tachypnea, recurrent chest infections, and respiratory distress, even in early infancy.
  • On chest X-ray: Multicystic mass, often with mediastinal shift.
  • Diagnosed prenatally or postnatally with imaging (X-ray/CT).
  • Management: Surgical resection-often done before 1 year due to risk of malignant transformation (e.g., pleuropulmonary blastoma).
  • Pathogenesis: Embryological injury before the 35th day of gestation disrupts bronchopulmonary development.

Explanation of other options:

Right-sided Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (Option B): Presents with severe respiratory distress immediately after birth, not recurrent infections. Bowel loops in the chest may shift mediastinum. Not typically associated with chronic recurrent chest infections in infancy.

Congenital Lobar Emphysema (Option C): Causes overinflation of a pulmonary lobe, leading to compression of adjacent structures and acute respiratory distress, usually at birth or within a few days. Recurrent infections are not a hallmark feature.

Cystic Fibrosis (Option D): Can cause chronic lung infections, but usually presents with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, clubbing, and positive sweat chloride test. Onset is typically later and more systemic in presentation.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6709284/

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and diffuse intracranial calcifications is the hallmark of congenital toxoplasmosis.

  • Congenital toxoplasmosis results from transplacental transmission of Toxoplasma gondii, particularly when maternal infection occurs during pregnancy.
  • The severity of fetal involvement depends on gestational age at the time of infection-early infection leads to more severe manifestations.
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications (often periventricular)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
  • Other features may include:
    • Microcephaly
    • Seizures
    • Developmental delays
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Hearing loss
  • Diagnosis:
    • Prenatal: PCR from amniotic fluid, serial ultrasounds
    • Postnatal: Serology (IgM/IgA), CSF PCR, neuroimaging
  • Treatment:
    • Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Folinic acid for 1 year
    • Spiramycin for maternal infection in the 1st trimester

Explanation of other options:

Dandy-Walker Malformation (Option B): Characterized by posterior fossa cyst, agenesis of cerebellar vermis, and hydrocephalus-does not present with intracranial calcifications or chorioretinitis.

Budd-Chiari Syndrome (Option C): Caused by hepatic vein obstruction, presenting with hepatomegaly, ascites, and abdominal pain-no CNS findings like calcifications or hydrocephalus.

Congenital Hydrocephalus (Option D): Refers only to ventricular enlargement due to CSF accumulation. It does not account for chorioretinitis or intracranial calcifications, which point to a specific etiology like toxoplasmosis.

choices.text: Defibrillate, check pulse and then perform CPR
Defibrillate, perform CPR, and then check the pulse

questions.text: A patient presents with no pulse, and the ECG shows the following rhythm. What is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
In a pulseless patient with a shockable rhythm like VT/VF, immediate defibrillation followed by CPR is the next best step as per ACLS protocol.

  • The ECG shows a shockable rhythm such as ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (pVT).
  • According to Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, the immediate priority is defibrillation to restore a perfusing rhythm.
  • After delivering the shock, chest compressions (CPR) must be resumed immediately without checking for a pulse to minimize downtime in circulation.
  • Pulse check is done only after 2 minutes (1 CPR cycle) or when signs of life return.
  • This approach maximizes the chance of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).

Explanation of other options:

Defibrillate, check pulse and then perform CPR (Option A): Incorrect - Pulse should not be checked immediately after shock. CPR must be resumed first to maintain perfusion.

Cardioversion (Option B): Incorrect - Synchronized cardioversion is indicated in tachyarrhythmias with a pulse (e.g., SVT, unstable AF), not pulseless VT/VF.

Administer epinephrine (Option D): Incorrect - Epinephrine is part of the next step if defibrillation fails, but the first step in a shockable rhythm is defibrillation, not drugs.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative
Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive

questions.text: A young man had a history of jaundice and raised HBsAg levels a year back. On follow-up now, he has normal levels of liver enzymes. His current profile is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis for his current condition?
questions.solution:
Persistent HBsAg positivity >6 months, HBeAg positivity, and anti-HBc IgG indicate chronic active Hepatitis B with ongoing viral replication.

  • The key diagnostic criteria for chronic Hepatitis B infection are:
    • Persistence of HBsAg for >6 months
    • Presence of anti-HBc IgG
    • Absence of anti-HBs
  • In this case, the patient continues to have HBsAg positivity after 1 year, indicating chronic infection.
  • The presence of HBeAg implies active viral replication and high infectivity.
  • Since anti-HBc IgG is positive and IgM is negative, the acute phase is over, confirming the chronic stage.
  • There are two main types of chronic Hepatitis B:
    • HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B: High infectivity, active replication
    • HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B (precore mutant): Lower replication, often inactive phase or fluctuating activity
  • The current serology fits the HBeAg-positive type, with active replication and potential for liver damage even if enzymes are temporarily normal.

Acute HBV infection with recovery

Chronic HBV infection

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/354997816_Hepatitis_B_Vaccines

questions.text: An elderly patient has hypercalcemia, elevated serum creatinine, and anaemia. Electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal spike. Her immunofixation test findings are given below. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the investigations, including electrophoresis showing a monoclonal spike and immunofixation revealing increased IgM levels (with a distinct band and no significant band formation above IgG), this patient is diagnosed with multiple myeloma with increased IgM.

Monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (Option D) is characterised by serum monoclonal protein (M-protein) levels <3 g/dL without end-organ damage, such as hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anaemia, or bone lesions (CRAB features). It is asymptomatic and has a 1% annual risk of progression to multiple myeloma or other plasma cell disorders.

questions.text: A 43-year-old farmer presents with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, burning red eyes, fever with chills, calf tenderness, and joint pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Leptospirosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with high fever, severe headache, muscle pain, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, and a history of exposure to flooded rice paddies.


Explanation for other options:

Dengue (Option A) presents with fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash but lacks conjunctival suffusion and calf tenderness.

Malaria (Option B) is characterised by cyclical fever, splenomegaly, but does not cause conjunctival suffusion.

Filariasis (Option D) leads to lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis, without conjunctival suffusion or myalgia.

questions.text: A patient with hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents with recurrent episodes of renal colic. Which diuretic is most suitable for use in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
A hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) experiencing frequent attacks of renal colic would benefit from Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic.

  • It helps manage hypertension and can reduce calcium excretion in urine, which is beneficial for preventing calcium-based kidney stones, a common cause of renal colic.

Explanation for other options:

Furosemide (Option A) is a loop diuretic that indeed causes increased calcium excretion in the urine, which can exacerbate symptoms of renal colic.

Mannitol (Option B), an osmotic diuretic, is used in acute settings and is not suitable for chronic conditions like CKD and renal colic.

Spironolactone (Option D), a potassium-sparing diuretic, is typically used for heart failure or aldosterone excess but not for preventing kidney stones or controlling hypertension in CKD.

questions.text: A child is born eight months following the death of the presumed father. Despite doubts about paternity from the paternal grandparents, DNA testing confirms the child is biologically related to their son. What term best describes this child?
questions.solution:
A posthumous child is one born after the death of the father. The scenario described fits this definition.

Explanation for other options:

Suppositious child (Option A):

  • This term describes a fictitious child where a woman may pretend to be pregnant and later present a living child as her own.
  • This can involve substituting one child for another or claiming a child after an abortion, typically for financial gain or to claim property.
  • In this case, there is no indication of deception or substitution, so this option does not apply.

Fabricated child (Option B): Fabricated or induced illness (FII) is an uncommon type of child abuse where a parent or caregiver intentionally exaggerates or causes symptoms of illness in a child.

Illegitimate child (Option D):
Also known as a bastard, this describes a child born out of lawful wedlock or not within a competent time after the dissolution of marriage.

  • In this scenario, the child is born to a woman who was married, making this option incorrect.
  • Certain conditions can render a child illegitimate, including if the alleged father is under the age of puberty, physically incapable of fathering children, not sexually accessible to the mother at the time of conception, or has blood group incompatibility.
  • Legitimate Child: A child born during a lawful marriage or within 280 days after the marriage has been dissolved by divorce or death of the husband, as long as the mother remains unmarried.

Reference

Fabricated or induced illness: From "Munchausen by proxy" to child and family-oriented action - PubMed

questions.text: A patient reports progressive visual decline three years following ocular surgery and presents with the condition shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is a common complication after cataract surgery.

  • It occurs when the posterior capsule of the lens becomes opacified, leading to decreased visual acuity and glare, particularly at night.
  • The symptoms of glare and decreased visual acuity, along with the fact that the patient has had cataract surgery within the last year, make PCO the most probable diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Pseudo-bullous keratopathy (Option A): This condition is due to endothelial dysfunction, leading to corneal oedema and bullae formation. Unlike PCO, it presents earlier and is associated with pain and photophobia rather than progressive vision loss.

Corneal dystrophy (Option B): Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, progressive, and hereditary corneal disorders affecting various corneal layers. They do not occur secondary to cataract surgery.

Posterior subcapsular cataract (Option C): PSC affects the posterior lens but occurs before cataract surgery, whereas PCO develops after cataract surgery.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK574505/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557865/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539699/

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department with repeated episodes of forceful, non-bilious vomiting. Based on the accompanying radiograph, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph reveals a thickened and elongated pyloric region, in conjunction with the clinical symptoms, which are indicative of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is caused by muscular hypertrophy of the pylorus, resulting in obstruction at the gastric outlet. It typically affects male infants between 2 to 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms: Repeated projectile vomiting that is non-bilious, usually following feeds, beginning at around 2-6 weeks of life.
  • Examination Findings: Observable gastric peristalsis and a firm, mobile, "olive-shaped" mass palpable in the epigastric area.

Diagnostic Approach:

  • Ultrasonography (preferred investigation):
    • Pyloric muscle thickness > 3 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • Elongated, thickened pyloric appearance (typically 10-14 mm)
  • Contrast-enhanced Upper GI Series (less commonly used):
    Reveals characteristic signs and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

Explanation for other options:

Annular pancreas (Option A): Can also cause non-bilious vomiting and is associated with Down syndrome and duodenal atresia, but the image and clinical context favour CHPS.

Duodenal atresia (Option C): Characterised by bilious vomiting and the classic "double bubble" appearance on X-ray.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option D): Typically presents with painless gastrointestinal bleeding, not vomiting.

questions.text: Identify the index explained in the image?
questions.solution:
The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels.

  • It is calculated by assessing three key dimensions of human development:
    • Life Expectancy at Birth: Reflects the ability to live a long and healthy life.
    • Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or more and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
    • Gross National Income (GNI) per Capita: Reflects the standard of living and economic conditions in a country, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

Explanation for other options:

Human Poverty Index (HPI) (Option C): It was developed to measure relative poverty, which refers to the lack of access to the facilities and services that others have. Indicators of HPI are:

  • Longevity: The proportion of people not surviving until the age of 40 years.
  • Knowledge: Adult Literacy Rate
  • Standard of living: No access to safe water supply and sanitation, and % of children underweight.

Multidimensional poverty index (Option D): MDPI complements traditional monetary poverty measures by capturing the acute deprivations in Health, Education, and Living standards. The Human Poverty Index (HPI) was replaced by the MPI in 2010, as it was not specific to any group of people.

Reference:

  1. Human Poverty Index (HPI) and Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) | communitymedicine4all
  2. Poverty threshold - Wikipedia
  3. 2023 Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) | Human Development Reports

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of "feeling tensed" along with an upset stomach, diarrhea, and heartburn. She mentions that her family members also experience similar symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tingling at extremities is a common somatic symptom in generalized anxiety disorder due to hyperventilation and autonomic arousal.

  • The clinical features described-chronic tension, gastrointestinal complaints like diarrhea and heartburn, and family history-are characteristic of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
  • In GAD, prolonged stress leads to autonomic hyperactivity, resulting in symptoms such as tingling or numbness in extremities, muscle tension, restlessness, and fatigue.
  • These somatic complaints often lead to repeated medical evaluations before a psychiatric diagnosis is made.
  • Hyperventilation and heightened sympathetic activity are commonly responsible for these paresthesias in anxiety disorders.

Explanation of other options:

Neologisms (Option A): Typically seen in schizophrenia, where patients create new, nonsensical words; not a feature of anxiety disorders.

Hallucinations (Option C): Involve false sensory perceptions without external stimuli, usually associated with psychotic disorders.

Idea of reference (Option D): A psychotic symptom where neutral events are perceived as having personal significance-commonly seen in schizophrenia and paranoid states, not in GAD.

choices.text: Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are positive and used as a screening test
A type of food allergy causing skin rashes
A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance
An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria

questions.text: What is Celiac Sprue in a child?
questions.solution:
Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder screened by detecting anti-tTG antibodies, especially in children presenting with gluten sensitivity symptoms.

  • Celiac sprue, or celiac disease, is a chronic autoimmune disorder triggered by ingestion of gluten (found in wheat, barley, rye)
  • It primarily affects the small intestine, leading to villous atrophy, malabsorption, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and growth failure in children.
  • The first-line screening test is the detection of anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) IgA antibodies, which are highly sensitive and specific for celiac disease.
  • If the antibody test is positive, it is typically followed by upper GI endoscopy with duodenal biopsy, which reveals:
    • Villous atrophy
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Intraepithelial lymphocytosis
  • Other relevant antibodies include:
    • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA)
    • Anti-gliadin antibodies (AGA) - less commonly used now
  • Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2/DQ8 genes and can also lead to secondary lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage.

Explanation of other options:

A type of food allergy causing skin rashes (Option B): Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition, not a classical IgE-mediated food allergy, although it may present with dermatitis herpetiformis, a blistering skin condition.

A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance (Option C): While celiac disease is genetic, it does not primarily cause lactose intolerance. However, lactose intolerance may occur secondarily due to villus damage impairing lactase enzyme activity.

An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria (Option D): Celiac disease is not an infectious disease; it is a non-infectious immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

questions.text: A patient presents with a generalized rash over the body, a greyish patch over the anal area, and characteristic hair changes as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of generalized rash, perianal condyloma lata, and moth-eaten alopecia is characteristic of secondary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • Secondary syphilis, caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum, typically occurs 6-12 weeks after the primary chancre heals.
  • It is characterized by systemic dissemination of the organism and presents with:
    • Generalized symmetrical maculopapular rash, often involving the palms and soles.
    • Condyloma lata - greyish, flat moist papules commonly seen in the perianal and genital region.
    • Moth-eaten alopecia - a patchy, non-scarring hair loss seen on the scalp.
  • These findings, especially when seen together, are highly suggestive of secondary syphilis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by serologic tests (e.g., VDRL/RPR and TPHA/FTA-ABS).
  • Treatment involves intramuscular benzathine penicillin G, which is the drug of choice.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Typically causes pustular or abscess-forming skin lesions like impetigo or folliculitis; it does not cause systemic rash with alopecia or perianal lesions as seen in syphilis.

Malassezia furfur (Option C): Causes pityriasis versicolor, which presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules, not generalized rash or hair loss.

Microsporum canis (Option D): A dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis with patchy scalp hair loss, but it does not cause perianal lesions or generalized body rash.

questions.text: Identify the procedure done.
questions.solution:
Total penectomy is the complete surgical removal of the penis, typically performed for advanced penile cancer.

  • Total penectomy is a surgical procedure involving the complete removal of the penis, usually performed for extensive penile malignancy, especially squamous cell carcinoma of the penis that cannot be treated with partial resection.
  • The urethral opening is relocated (perineal urethrostomy) to allow continued urinary function.
  • The urethral opening is relocated (perineal urethrostomy) to allow continued urinary function.
  • This procedure results in the absence of visible penile tissue, consistent with the image shown in such questions.
  • It is important to differentiate this from other related procedures based on anatomical structures removed and clinical indications.

Explanation of other options:

Orchidectomy (Option A): Involves removal of one or both testicles, typically performed for testicular tumors or as androgen deprivation therapy in prostate cancer. It does not involve penile tissue.

Partial penectomy (Option C): Involves removal of only part of the penis, preserving some penile shaft for urinary and sexual function. In the image of total removal, this is ruled out.

Hernioplasty (Option D): A hernia repair surgery, usually involving mesh reinforcement of the inguinal or abdominal wall. It does not involve genital organ excision.

Reference: Penectomy: Surgery to Treat Cancer of the Penis

choices.text: LBC, HPV antigen testing, Cervical biopsy
Pap smear, HSV testing, Cervical biopsy
Pap smear, HBV DNA, Cervical biopsy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of spotting and foul-smelling discharge for the past 2 months. On examination, cervical erosions are seen.
questions.solution:
LBC with HPV testing and cervical biopsy offers the most comprehensive evaluation for cervical dysplasia and malignancy.

  • In a woman presenting with abnormal vaginal discharge, intermenstrual spotting, and visible cervical erosion, the clinical concern includes cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) or early cervical carcinoma, particularly in the context of persistent infection by high-risk HPV types.
  • Hence, a triple assessment is warranted:
    • LBC (Liquid-Based Cytology): Modern alternative to conventional Pap smear, with better cell preservation and less debris.Useful for identifying cytological abnormalities like koilocytes, dyskaryosis, and CIN.
    • HPV antigen testing: Essential for detecting high-risk HPV strains (especially 16, 18), which are implicated in >95% of cervical cancers.
    • Cervical biopsy: Provides a histopathological diagnosis to confirm dysplasia or malignancy, especially when there are suspicious cervical lesions or persistent symptoms.
  • This combination maximizes diagnostic sensitivity and guides further management (colposcopy, LEEP, etc.).

Explanation of other options:

Pap smear, HSV testing, Cervical biopsy (Option B): HSV testing is not warranted here as there's no vesicular lesion or ulcerative complaint suggestive of herpes. Pap smear is acceptable, but LBC is superior.

Pap smear, HBV DNA, Cervical biopsy (Option C): HBV DNA is unrelated to cervical complaints; it is relevant in liver disease, not gynecological evaluation.

LBC, HSV testing only (Option D): Missing HPV testing and biopsy-two essential components in evaluating pre-malignant/malignant cervical lesions.

Reference:https://www.nature.com/articles/6605328

questions.text: What diagnostic procedure is being illustrated in the image provided?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a barium swallow study, a specialised imaging procedure that uses barium sulfate contrast to visualise the oesophagus, pharynx, and upper gastrointestinal tract under fluoroscopic guidance. This investigation is commonly employed to assess:

  • Oesophagal narrowing or strictures
  • Achalasia (seen as a classic "bird-beak" tapering)
  • Esophageal cancer
  • Hiatal hernia
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

Explanation for other options:

Fluoroscopy (Option A): Fluoroscopy is the imaging technique used during a barium swallow, but the test itself is not called fluoroscopy; rather, it's termed based on the anatomical focus-here, a barium swallow.

X-ray for alkali ingestion (Option C): Though alkali ingestion leads to deep tissue damage, plain X-rays are usually not diagnostic unless complications like perforation or pneumomediastinum occur. A barium study is used later to detect post-injury strictures.

X-ray for acid ingestion (Option D): Acid ingestion often damages the stomach due to coagulative necrosis. Plain abdominal X-rays are rarely helpful for early diagnosis. Follow-up contrast studies, like a barium swallow, are more useful in detecting long-term complications.

References:

  1. Barium swallow | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org
  2. Normal indentations on the oesophagus in barium swallow
  3. Definition of barium-meal photofluorography - NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms
  4. Barium Tests (Barium Meal, Swallow, Follow Through)
  5. Double contrast barium enema technique | Radiology Reference Article

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents with a history of ear discharge for 2 weeks. On examination, a mild perforation is observed in the antero-inferior segment of the tympanic membrane. What is the expected result from Rinne's test?
questions.solution:
A perforation in the tympanic membrane typically results in conductive hearing loss (Rinne's negative), as the perforation disrupts the normal conduction of sound through the middle ear.

  • When performing Rinne's test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), Rinne's negative would be expected in cases of conductive hearing loss, meaning that bone conduction (BC) is heard louder than air conduction (AC).
  • In the presence of a tympanic membrane perforation, air conduction is compromised due to the disrupted integrity of the eardrum, while bone conduction remains relatively intact.
  • Therefore, the result would likely be Rinne's negative, where the patient hears the tuning fork louder when placed on the mastoid (bone conduction) compared to in front of the ear canal (air conduction).

Explanation for other options:

Rinne's positive (Option A): Incorrect because Rinne's positive is seen in sensorineural hearing loss or when conductive hearing is intact, which is not expected in the case of a tympanic membrane perforation.

Rinne's equivocal (Option C): Incorrect because an equivocal result is rare in this situation. The perforation typically causes a clear conductive hearing loss, making the result more definitive (negative).

Cannot be determined (Option D): Incorrect because, based on the presence of a tympanic membrane perforation, we can reasonably predict Rinne's negative.

choices.text: Separation from parents leading to depression

questions.text: A child with untreated ADHD is most likely to develop which of the following disorders during adolescence?
questions.solution:
Untreated Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in childhood is associated with an increased risk of developing Conduct Disorder during adolescence.

  • Children with ADHD often display impulsivity, aggression, and difficulty following rules, which may escalate into more severe behavioural problems, including violating the rights of others and engaging in antisocial behaviour.

Explanation for other options:

Binge eating (Option A) is not typically associated with untreated ADHD, although some individuals with ADHD may engage in emotional eating.

Selective mutism (Option B) is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and is not directly linked to ADHD.

Separation from parent leading to depression (Option C) is not a common progression from ADHD, though emotional difficulties can arise, especially in children with comorbid conditions

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a history of prolonged fever with discolouration of the skin over the lower limb and oedema. Microscopy reveals a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis.

The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail.

Brugia timori:

  • Periodicity: Nocturnal
  • Vector: Anopheles barbirostris

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumour, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.solution:
VHL is associated with both clear cell Renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

  • Autosomal dominant disorder of VHL gene on chromosome 3p.

It is associated with

  • Cerebellar Hemangioblastomas: Highly vascular tumours in the central nervous system, especially the cerebellum.
  • Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC): Often clear cell type, multifocal and bilateral
  • Retinal hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

Explanation for other options:

NF (Neurofibromatosis) (Option B)

  • Type 1 (NF1): Characterized by cutaneous neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and optic gliomas.
  • Type 2 (NF2): Associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal tumours.
  • Neurofibromatosis does not involve renal tumours or cerebellar hemangioblastomas.

TSC (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex) (Option C) is caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes. It is associated with Angiofibromas, cortical tubers, subependymal giant cell astrocytomas, and renal angiomyolipomas.

Li-Fraumeni Syndrome is caused by a mutation in the TP53 gene (Option D): It is associated with multiple sarcomas, breast cancer, leukaemia, and brain tumours.

Reference: Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome | Treatment & Management | Point of Care

questions.text: A patient has severe abdominal pain and raised lipase levels. Imaging shows a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). Which additional enzyme is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Gamma-glutamyl transferase levels are elevated in bile duct obstruction, such as a stone in the common bile duct, along with alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

LDH (Option B) Elevated LDH levels may indicate cell damage or injury in various organs. LDH is a non-specific marker; its levels can be elevated due to various conditions affecting different organs.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482489/

questions.text: Identify the nerve marked in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The medial pectoral nerve innervates the pectoralis minor and pectoralis major muscles. It originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus and courses through the axilla to supply these muscles, making it the correct answer in this context.

Explanation for other options:

Lateral pectoral nerve (Option B): This nerve also innervates the pectoralis major muscle but originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, running in a slightly different pathway compared to the medial pectoral nerve.

Long thoracic nerve (Option C): This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, which is located along the lateral chest wall. It doesn't fit with the labelling in the image if it's marking the pectoral muscles.

Thoracodorsal nerve (Option D): This nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle, located on the back and not in the region of the pectoral muscles.

Reference: Medscape - When is a modified radical mastectomy indicated

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with an irregularly irregular pulse and dyspnoea. The expected finding in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is
questions.solution:
In the JVP waveform, the 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. In atrial fibrillation, which has an irregularly irregular pulse, there is no coordinated atrial contraction, leading to the absence of the 'a' wave in the JVP.

Explanation for other options:

Cannon a wave (Option B):

  • They are large, prominent waves in the JVP that occur when atrial contraction is against a closed tricuspid valve, often due to arrhythmias like complete heart block.

Prominent X descent (Option C):

  • The X descent in the JVP represents atrial relaxation and descent of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole.
  • Prominent X descent is generally seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation or right ventricular failure.

Prominent Y descent (Option D):

  • The Y descent reflects the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.
  • Prominent Y descent can be seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis or right heart failure.

questions.text: A patient's X-ray shows cardiomegaly, and they present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of cardiomegaly, hypotonia, macroglossia and hepatosplenomegaly are suggestive of Pompe's disease.

Explanation for other options:

Ebstein anomaly (Option B) is associated with atrialisation of the ventricle and a history of lithium exposure in the antenatal period, and it does not present with hypotonia.

Down syndrome (Option C): It does not present with hypotonia after birth

Cori Disease (Option D) involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly.

Reference: Pompe disease diagnosis and management guideline - PMC

questions.text: A group of 80 people was studied to assess the effect of diet modification on mean cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Which statistical test is most appropriate to compare the mean cholesterol levels before and after the diet modification?
questions.solution:
The paired t-test is the most appropriate test for comparing the mean cholesterol levels before and after diet modification in the same group of individuals.

  • This test accounts for the fact that the data are paired (pre- and post-diet modification) and assesses whether the mean difference is statistically significant.

Reference:

Review Article On Parametric And Nonparametric Test

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of repeated urinary tract infections, a weak urinary stream, and failure to thrive. On examination, his abdomen appears distended, and a palpable bladder is noted. The micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation with recurrent UTIs, poor stream, distended abdomen, palpable bladder, and poor growth is characteristic of posterior urethral valves (PUV), a congenital condition causing urinary tract obstruction in male children.

MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram) findings in PUV:

  • Dilated posterior urethra
  • Thickened bladder wall
  • Possible vesicoureteral reflux

Ultrasound features:

  • Classic keyhole sign, due to dilation of the posterior urethra and a distended bladder

Management:

  • Cystoscopic valve ablation is the initial and definitive treatment. It involves endoscopic removal of the obstructive posterior urethral valves, thus relieving the obstruction and preventing progressive renal damage.

Explanation for other options:

Urethral reconstruction (Option B): Reserved for cases where obstruction persists or in severe damage post-ablation; not first-line.

Intermittent catheterisation (Option C): May offer short-term relief, but doesn't resolve the anatomical obstruction.

Bladder augmentation surgery (Option D): Used in conditions like neurogenic bladder with small capacity, not in primary obstructive disorders like PUV.

Reference:

  1. Posterior urethral valves

Keyhole sign (posterior urethral valves)

questions.text: In the event of a death resulting from a road traffic accident, which authority is responsible for requesting an autopsy?
questions.solution:
In cases of Road Traffic Accidents (RTA), the police are responsible for ordering the autopsy. This is part of their duty to investigate the circumstances of the death and to ensure that the legal procedures are followed correctly. (Option A, C and D ruled out)

  • If the cause of death is unclear or if required for legal reasons, the police will request an autopsy to establish the cause of death.

Key Takeaway:

In India, medico-legal post-mortem examinations are carried out upon receiving a written order from a police officer, as authorised under Section 174 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC), or from a magistrate under Section 176 of the CrPC, depending on the case's circumstances.

Reference

Medico-legal autopsies after sunset: Ethical issues

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates the locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1 hour before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: Caffeine impairs sleep by which of the following:
questions.solution:
Caffeine works by blocking adenosine receptors.

  • Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep by slowing down nerve activity. By blocking adenosine, caffeine prevents the brain from sensing sleepiness, thereby promoting wakefulness.

Explanation for other options:

Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness (Option B): The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in arousal and wakefulness. While it does play a role in promoting wakefulness, caffeine's primary mechanism of action is not through direct activation of the locus coeruleus.

No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1 hour before sleep (Option C): Caffeine is well-known for its role in maintaining wakefulness by counteracting sleep-promoting mechanisms in the brain.

Activates histamine release and prevents sleep (Option D): Histamine is involved in promoting wakefulness, but caffeine does not directly cause histamine release. Its effect on sleep is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade rather than histamine pathways.

Key Takeaway:

Metabolic Theory

There are 2 centres located in the hypothalamus, which are in constant mutual inhibition.

  • Wake-Promoting Area: Located in the posterior hypothalamus- Tuberomammillary nucleus (TMN), releasing histamine.
    • The wake-promoting area stimulates two important nuclei of the reticular activating system, i.e., Raphe nuclei (RN), which produce serotonin, and Locus coeruleus (LC), which produces norepinephrine.
    • These act at the level of the thalamus, from which all the diffuse projections will reach the cortex, and the active cortex means the person will remain awake.
    • This active cortex indefinitely produces metabolites with awakeness, primarily Adenosine.
    • An increase in adenosine acts at the level of the basal forebrain and stimulates the sleep-promoting area.
  • Sleep-Promoting Area: Located in the anterior hypothalamus- Ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO), releasing GABA.

References: UCSD

questions.text: Which artery lies in front of the Achilles and behind the medial malleolus?
questions.solution:
The posterior tibial artery passes behind the medial malleolus and runs in front of the Achilles tendon, within the tarsal tunnel. It provides blood supply to the posterior compartment of the leg and the plantar surface of the foot.

Explanation for other options:

Peroneal artery (Option B): It runs along the lateral compartment of the leg and does not pass behind the medial malleolus.

Anterior tibial artery (Option C): It passes anteriorly through the interosseous membrane and does not course behind the medial malleolus.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option D): It is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery and is located on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue and hemoptysis. His hemoglobin has dropped from 12 g/dL to 8 g/dL in one week. Bronchoalveolar lavage reveals a reddish fluid, and his serum creatinine is elevated at 1.7 mg/dL. He tests ANCA-positive, and a renal biopsy shows pauci-immune glomerulonephritis without granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic polyangiitis presents with ANCA-positive pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and pulmonary-renal syndrome, without granulomas.

  • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a pauci-immune small vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.
  • The hallmark features include:
    • Hemoptysis (due to alveolar hemorrhage)
    • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (causing a drop in hemoglobin, elevated creatinine)
    • ANCA positivity - typically p-ANCA (anti-MPO antibodies)
    • Pauci-immune pattern on renal biopsy (minimal immune complex deposition)
    • Absence of granulomatous inflammation (unlike GPA or Churg-Strauss)
  • This clinical presentation of pulmonary-renal syndrome, especially with no granulomas, strongly favors MPA.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option C): SLE causes immune complex-mediated (not pauci-immune) nephritis and is typically ANA positive. It does not usually present with ANCA-positive vasculitis or isolated pulmonary-renal syndrome.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (Option D): HSP is an IgA-mediated vasculitis seen mainly in children, with purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. Pulmonary hemorrhage and ANCA positivity are uncommon.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear a cast?
questions.solution:
A 5th metatarsal fracture typically requires casting for 6-8 weeks to ensure adequate healing and prevent complications like non-union.

  • The 5th metatarsal, especially the proximal portion, is prone to fractures, commonly referred to as Jones fractures when they occur at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction.
  • This region has relatively poor blood supply, so adequate immobilization is crucial to allow proper healing.
  • The standard management involves non-weight-bearing immobilization in a cast or walking boot for 6-8 weeks.
  • Healing is monitored with follow-up radiographs.
  • Surgery is considered if the fracture is displaced, comminuted, or fails to unite (non-union).
  • Early or inadequate immobilization risks delayed healing and long-term dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

2-3 weeks (Option A): Too short for complete bone healing, especially in a region with poor blood supply like the 5th metatarsal base.

3-5 weeks (Option B): Also inadequate for ensuring solid bone union and may lead to refracture or non-union.

16-20 weeks (Option D): Excessively long for an uncomplicated 5th metatarsal fracture and generally only considered in cases of delayed or non-union.

Reference:

https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22247-fifth-metatarsal-fracture

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stable vitals and an ECG showing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
In a hemodynamically stable child with PSVT, the first-line treatment is IV adenosine at an initial dose of 0.1 mg/kg.

  • Paroxysmal supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT) is a common pediatric arrhythmia characterized by a sudden onset of narrow complex tachycardia.
  • In children with stable hemodynamics, adenosine is the drug of choice due to its short half-life and effectiveness in blocking AV nodal conduction, thereby terminating the reentrant circuit.
  • The initial dose of adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg IV as a rapid bolus.
  • If ineffective, the dose can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg.
  • It must be followed by a saline flush and should be given via a central line or proximal IV for maximal effect.
  • The drug works by causing transient AV block, which often restores sinus rhythm in AVNRT or AVRT.
  • Before adenosine, vagal maneuvers (like Valsalva or ice pack to the face in infants) are attempted.
  • ECG findings in PSVT:
    • Regular rhythm
    • Narrow QRS complexes (<120 ms)
    • P waves often not visible or retrograde
    • HR: 180-250 bpm in children

Fig: Typical AVNRT terminated by carotid sinus massage

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion (Option A): Used in hemodynamically unstable PSVT or when adenosine fails. This child is stable, so it's not first-line.

Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg (Option B): This is the second-line dose used if 0.1 mg/kg fails. Not appropriate as the initial dose.

IV Adrenaline (Option D): Not indicated in PSVT. Adrenaline is reserved for cardiac arrest (asystole, PEA) or anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with recurrent diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools. A colonoscopy reveals yellowish-white raised plaques over the colonic mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pseudomembranous colitis presents with characteristic yellowish-white pseudomembranes on colonoscopy, typically following antibiotic use.

  • Pseudomembranous colitis is an acute colonic inflammatory condition most often caused by Clostridium difficile infection, usually following antibiotic use (especially cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluoroquinolones).
  • Pathophysiology: C. difficile produces toxins (Toxin A and B) that damage the colonic mucosa, leading to inflammation, necrosis, and the formation of pseudomembranes.
  • Colonoscopy Findings:
    • Presence of raised yellow-white plaques (pseudomembranes) on an erythematous mucosal background.
    • These plaques are made of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and necrotic debris.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Profuse watery or foul-smelling diarrhea
    • Abdominal cramps, fever
    • Recurrent or persistent symptoms after antibiotic use
  • Diagnosis:
    • Stool toxin assays (ELISA for toxin A/B)
    • Colonoscopy (in severe or recurrent cases)
  • Treatment:
    • Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin (first-line)
    • Metronidazole (alternative in mild cases)
    • Fecal microbiota transplantation (for recurrent cases)

Explanation of other options:

Familial adenomatous polyposis (Option B): Characterized by numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon, often without diarrhea or plaques. Colonoscopy reveals multiple small polyps, not pseudomembranes.

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Presents with bloody diarrhea and continuous mucosal inflammation on colonoscopy, usually starting at the rectum. Pseudomembranes are not seen.

Acute gastritis (Option D): Affects the stomach, not colon. Presents with epigastric pain, nausea, not diarrhea. Diagnosed by upper GI endoscopy, not colonoscopy.

questions.text:
A study is conducted on the association between the intake of vitamin C and the occurrence of respiratory illness. What is the order in which the following steps are conducted?
A. Select a case and control.
B. Matching
C. Measure total exposure
D. Analysis
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of a case-control study is:

  1. Select a case and a control
  2. Matching
  3. Measure total exposure
  4. Analysis

questions.text: Based on the CT image provided, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT scan reveals the presence of multiple cystic lesions in both kidneys, a hallmark feature of polycystic kidney disease (PKD), particularly autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

Explanation for other options:

Renal cyst (Option A): Typically presents as a single, well-defined unilocular cyst with thin walls and no internal septations or solid components.

CT showing a single cyst in the right kidney

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option B): Appears as a solid renal mass with heterogeneous enhancement due to areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, or calcification.

CT scan showing Renal cell carcinoma

Renal angiomyolipoma (Option D): A benign renal tumour containing fat, smooth muscle, and blood vessels. On CT, it shows fat-density areas, often appearing as a "dirty black" lesion due to fat content, sometimes with hemorrhagic changes.

Angiomyolipoma

Reference: ADPKD

questions.text: A patient with hypertension discontinued his antihypertensive medication due to complaints of dry mouth, dry eyes, and constipation. Shortly after stopping the drug, he presented with a hypertensive emergency, with blood pressure exceeding 180/120 mmHg. Which medication was he most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It works by decreasing sympathetic outflow, which lowers blood pressure. When clonidine is stopped abruptly, it can lead to a rebound increase in blood pressure (Withdrawal syndrome), potentially causing a hypertensive emergency.

  • Withdrawal syndrome is characterized by various symptoms, including headache, apprehension, tremors, abdominal pain, sweating, and tachycardia.
    • Typically, this occurs 18 to 36 hours after stopping the medication
    • Management: Resume Clonidine administration and Phentolamine is considered the drug of choice for a hypertensive crisis

Explanation for other options:

Lisinopril (Option B) is an ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Discontinuing lisinopril does not typically lead to rebound hypertension. Common side effects include cough and elevated potassium levels, but dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation are not associated with lisinopril. Thus, a hypertensive emergency after stopping lisinopril is unlikely.

Amlodipine (Option C) is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to manage hypertension and angina. Amlodipine does not cause rebound hypertension when stopped. Its side effects can include swelling, dizziness, and flushing, but dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation are not common. Therefore, stopping amlodipine would not typically lead to a hypertensive emergency.

Telmisartan (Option D) is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). Similar to lisinopril, discontinuing telmisartan does not cause rebound hypertension. Common side effects include dizziness and hyperkalemia but not dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation. A hypertensive emergency is unlikely to occur with the abrupt discontinuation of telmisartan.

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with corneal ulcers and diminished vision. He was very careless about his lens fluid. On microscopy, an organism with spikes is identified. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of corneal ulcer, spikes seen on microscopy and history of improper contact lens use is suggestive of Acanthamoeba infection.

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites.
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes:
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.

choices.text: Type 2 Von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency.
Type 3 Von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of the Von Willebrand factor.
Type 1 Von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood.
Type 2 Von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Von Willebrand's disease?
questions.solution: Type 1 Von Willebrand disease presents with mild bleeding as there is only a mild deficiency of vWF.

questions.text: A patient presents with anaemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair. Which micronutrient deficiency is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Anaemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmented skin and hair are seen in copper deficiency.

Explanation for other options:

Zinc (Option A) deficiency presents with poor Wound healing, skin Lesions: Rashes, dermatitis, hyperkeratosis, alopecia, impaired spermatogenesis, decreased T and B lymphocyte counts, impaired macrophage function and Acrodermatitis Enteropathica. It does not present with hypopigmentation.

Fluoride (Option B) deficiency presents with caries and dental problems.

Selenium (Option D) deficiency presents with Keshan disease. It is characterised by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac enlargement.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicle?
questions.solution:
The Na/l symporter (NIS) is responsible for the active transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells. It uses the sodium gradient to co-transport iodine into the cell from the bloodstream.

Pendrin (Option B):

  • Pendrin is an iodide/chloride exchanger located on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells.
  • It is involved in the movement of iodide into the follicle lumen but not in the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells.

CI/I symporter (Option C): This option is incorrect, as there is no known CI/I symporter in the thyroid.

Learning objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent fatigue, bleeding from the gums, and hair changes. On examination, he has pallor, diffuse hair loss, and noticeable depigmentation of scalp hair. Which of the following trace element deficiencies best explains his clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Zinc deficiency leads to anemia, alopecia, depigmented hair, and bleeding gums-findings all present in this patient.

  • Zinc is a vital trace element that serves as a cofactor in over 300 enzymatic reactions, playing crucial roles in immune function, protein and nucleic acid synthesis, wound healing, and cell division.
  • It is also essential for maintaining healthy skin, mucosa, and hair pigmentation.
  • In this patient, the combination of:
    • Anemia
    • Bleeding gums
    • Diffuse alopecia
    • Depigmented hair
    • Strongly suggests a zinc deficiency.
  • These findings result from impaired cellular functions due to inadequate activity of zinc-dependent enzymes.
  • Clinical Features of Zinc Deficiency:
    • Dermatologic: Dry, scaly skin, poor wound healing, alopecia, hair depigmentation
    • Hematologic: Anemia (due to poor iron utilization)
    • Oral: Bleeding gums, glossitis
    • Immune: Increased susceptibility to infections
    • Neurologic/Psychiatric: Mood changes, irritability
    • Growth & Development: Hypogonadism, growth retardation in children
  • It is commonly seen in individuals with:
    • Poor nutritional intake (especially low animal protein diets)
    • Malabsorption syndromes
    • Chronic liver disease
    • Alcoholism
    • Increased zinc losses through diarrhea

Explanation of other options:

Copper (Option A): Copper deficiency can cause microcytic anemia and neutropenia, and sometimes peripheral neuropathy, but hair depigmentation and bleeding gums are more characteristic of zinc deficiency.

Iron (Option B): Iron deficiency anemia presents with fatigue, pallor, and spoon nails, but does not typically cause bleeding gums, alopecia, or hair depigmentation, which are more specific to zinc deficiency.

Fluoride (Option C): Fluoride is mainly involved in dental and skeletal health. Deficiency increases the risk of dental caries, but does not produce systemic symptoms such as anemia or hair changes.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4082809/

questions.text: Identify the amputation shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows an amputation through the tibia and fibula, indicating a below-knee amputation.

  • A below-knee amputation (BKA), or transtibial amputation, involves surgical removal of the leg below the knee joint while preserving the knee.
  • In this procedure, both the tibia and fibula are transected, and the patella and femur are left intact.
  • This allows for better prosthetic control and more energy-efficient ambulation compared to above-knee amputation.
  • The preserved knee joint plays a crucial role in gait biomechanics.
  • BKA is commonly performed for causes like trauma, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes-related complications, or malignancy.
  • The radiographic appearance shows the amputation level clearly involving the mid-to-proximal third of the tibia and fibula.

Explanation of other options:

Above elbow amputation (Option C): Involves amputation through the humerus, removing the forearm and hand, completely unrelated to tibial and fibular anatomy.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546594/#article-17484.s4

questions.text: At which of the following ages does maximum brain growth occur?
questions.solution:
Maximum brain growth occurs during the first year of life, with the brain reaching approximately 60% of its adult size by 1 year.

  • The first year of life is the most critical period for brain development, both in terms of volume expansion and neural connectivity.
  • During this time:
    • The brain increases rapidly in weight and size.
    • Synaptogenesis, dendritic growth, and myelination accelerate.
    • The anterior fontanelle remains open to accommodate this rapid growth.
  • Brain growth milestones:
    • At birth: Brain is ~25% of adult size.
    • At 1 year: ~60% of adult size.
    • At 2 years: ~75% of adult size.
    • At 3 years: ~80-85% of adult size.
    • At 4 years: ~90% of adult size.
    • By 6-7 years: Nearly 95% of adult brain volume is achieved.
  • Despite early structural development, functional maturation (e.g., cognition, language, memory) continues through adolescence.

Explanation of other options:

2 years (Option B): The brain reaches ~75% of adult size, but the peak growth rate has already passed.

3 years (Option C): The brain is ~80-85% of adult size. Growth is ongoing but significantly slower.

4 years (Option D): Brain is ~90% of adult size. Most of the structural growth is completed, but functional development persists.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 50,000 cells/cu.mm, and petechiae and purpura. What is the recommended drug treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Vincristine + Prednisolone is the standard induction regimen for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most likely diagnosis in this child.

  • The child presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, hepatosplenomegaly, and petechiae, which are classic features of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)-the most common leukemia in children.
  • Initial treatment (induction phase) for ALL aims to achieve complete remission and involves:
    • Vincristine (microtubule inhibitor, halts cell division)
    • Prednisolone (a glucocorticoid, induces apoptosis in lymphoblasts)
  • These agents form the backbone of initial therapy, especially in low-risk or standard-risk ALL.
  • Phases of ALL treatment:
    • Induction therapy: Vincristine + Prednisolone (± L-asparaginase, daunorubicin based on risk stratification)
    • Consolidation: To eliminate residual disease and CNS-directed therapy
    • Maintenance therapy: To prevent relapse using methotrexate, 6-MP, etc.
    • Supportive care: Includes acyclovir for viral prophylaxis and cotrimoxazole for pneumocystis prophylaxis.

Explanation of other options:

IVIG (Option B): Used in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), not in leukemia. It reduces immune-mediated platelet destruction but doesn't treat leukemic cell proliferation.

L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone (Option C): While this combination is also used in ALL therapy, it typically forms part of expanded induction or consolidation phases. Vincristine + Prednisolone is more appropriate for initial induction.

Daunorubicin + Prednisolone (Option D): This combination is more commonly used in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). In ALL, daunorubicin is reserved for high-risk or poor prognosis subtypes.

questions.text: A mother brings her child with complaints of papular lesions on the extensor surfaces of the skin. The lesions improve following supplementation with vitamins A and C along with essential amino acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phrynoderma is a manifestation of nutritional deficiency involving Vitamin A, E or essential fatty acids (EFAs), particularlylinoleic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) and alpha-linolenic acid (an omega-3 fatty acid).

  • These fatty acids are crucial for maintaining the integrity and function of the skin barrier. A deficiency can lead to dry, scaly skin.
  • Characterised by the presence of small, rough, cone-shaped papules (follicular hyperkeratosis) on the skin, typically on the outer surface of the upper arms, thighs, buttocks, and sometimes on the face.
  • Can be asymptomatic or associated with mild itching.

Treatment

  • Intake of foods rich in omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, such as fish, nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils.
  • Treating any underlying conditions contributing to malabsorption or dietary restrictions.
  • Emollients and moisturisers.

Explanation for other options:

Rickets (Option B): This is a condition resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to weak and soft bones in children. Symptoms include bone deformities and growth retardation, but it does not typically present with papules on the extensor surfaces.

Kwashiorkor (Option C): This is a form of protein-energy malnutrition characterised by oedema, irritability, and skin changes. It usually involves more generalised symptoms of malnutrition rather than isolated papules that resolve with vitamins and amino acids.

Marasmus (Option D): This is another form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency in caloric intake, leading to severe weight loss and muscle wasting. It does not present with papules but rather with severe overall wasting.

Reference:

https://www.google.com/url?q=https://openi.nlm.nih.gov/detailedresult?img%3DPMC2854467_IJO-58-175-g001%26query%3Dphrynoderma%26it%3Dxg%26lic%3Dby%26req%3D4%26npos%3D1&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1725598974523732&usg=AOvVaw2pmVc81oBk4rcdkVUo-YxR

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with respiratory distress, and he is diagnosed with pan-acinar emphysema. Which deficiency is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of Alpha-1 antitrypsin leads to panacinar emphysema along with liver cirrhosis.

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition characterised by low levels or dysfunctional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • Normal individuals have the PiMM genotype, while those with the disease have the PiZZ genotype.
  • This results in significantly reduced levels of functional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • Carriers possess the PiMZ genotype.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

The image below shows centriacinar emphysema.

The image below shows paraseptal emphysema.

Type 1 alveolar cells(Option A) are squamous cells responsible for gas exchange in the alveoli. Dysfunction or loss of these cells can impair gas exchange, but does not cause emphysema or structural destruction of alveoli.

Type 2 alveolar cells(Option C) produce surfactant and play a role in alveolar repair. Their dysfunction leads to surfactant deficiency, contributing to conditions like neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, not emphysema.

Albumin (Option D) is a plasma protein involved in maintaining oncotic pressure and the transport of substances. It has no role in the structural integrity of alveoli or the pathogenesis of emphysema.

Key Takeaway:

A-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency:

  • Gene on Chromosome 14
    • PiMM: Normal
    • PiZZ: Diseased
    • PiMZ: Carrier
  • Organs affected :
    • Lungs: Pan-acinar emphysema
    • Liver: Cirrhosis

questions.text: A child presents with malnutrition and multiple follicular, dry papules on the elbows and knees. Improvement of the skin lesions is observed following vitamin supplementation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phrynoderma is a follicular hyperkeratotic disorder associated with multiple vitamin deficiencies, especially vitamin A, and improves with vitamin supplementation.

  • Phrynoderma, also known as toad skin, is a condition characterized by dry, horny follicular papules distributed commonly on extensor surfaces like elbows, knees, buttocks, and thighs.
  • It is seen in malnourished individuals, particularly children, and is attributed to multiple nutritional deficiencies, especially:
    • Vitamin A
    • Vitamin C, Vitamin E,
    • B-complex vitamins, and
    • Essential fatty acids
  • The papules are due to follicular plugging and hyperkeratosis, giving the skin a rough texture.
  • The hallmark of the diagnosis is improvement of the lesions with vitamin and nutritional supplementation.

Explanation of other options:

Keratosis Pilaris (Option B): Though also present with follicular papules, it is a genetic condition unrelated to malnutrition or vitamin deficiency, and typically does not improve with vitamin supplementation.

Darier Disease (Option C): A genetic disorder of keratinization presenting with greasy, warty papules in seborrheic areas (chest, back, forehead); not related to malnutrition and does not improve with vitamins.

Lichen Planus (Option D): An autoimmune inflammatory condition with flat-topped, violaceous, itchy papules, often involving wrists and oral mucosa-does not resemble follicular papules or respond to vitamin therapy

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with confusion. He is taking antihypertensive medication and aspirin following a recent myocardial infarction. He recalls a minor fall from a chair three weeks ago. His neurological exam is otherwise normal. Based on the radiograph provided, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Subdural hematoma presents with delayed confusion after minor trauma in elderly patients, especially those on antiplatelets or anticoagulants.

  • A subdural hematoma (SDH) results from rupture of the bridging veins between the brain and dura, commonly following minor head trauma.
  • Elderly patients and those on blood thinners (like aspirin) are particularly susceptible.
  • The bleeding accumulates slowly and may become symptomatic days to weeks after the initial injury, as seen in this patient presenting with confusion weeks after a fall.
  • CT scan typically shows a crescent-shaped lesion that can vary in density depending on the age of the bleed:
    • Acute: hyperdense
    • Subacute: isodense
    • Chronic: hypodense
  • This delayed onset of confusion and classic imaging features are consistent with chronic subdural hematoma.

Comparison between epidural and subdural hematoma:

Explanation of other options:

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option C): Presents with sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life"), not confusion. CT shows hyperdensity in the basal cisterns and sulci, not a crescentic lesion.

Cerebellar Contusion (Option D): Would show focal hemorrhage in the cerebellum with neurological signs like ataxia or dysmetria, not diffuse confusion.

questions.text: A patient presents with weakness of the right upper and lower limbs, along with left-sided facial nerve palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left side. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Foville syndrome results from a pontine lesion affecting the abducens nucleus, facial nerve, and corticospinal tract, producing ipsilateral facial and gaze palsy with contralateral hemiparesis.

  • The clinical presentation of right-sided hemiparesis (upper and lower limbs), along with left-sided cranial nerve VII palsy and horizontal gaze palsy to the left, is characteristic of Foville syndrome.
  • This syndrome arises from a lesion in the dorsal pons, typically involving the abducens nucleus (CN VI), facial nerve fascicles (CN VII), paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), and corticospinal tract.
  • Key findings in Foville syndrome include:
    • Ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy (due to abducens nucleus or PPRF involvement)
    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial palsy
    • Contralateral hemiparesis from corticospinal tract involvement
  • These findings distinguish Foville from other pontine syndromes that may share overlapping features but lack conjugate gaze deficits.

Brainstem stroke syndromes

  • Foville Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis + Conjugate gaze paralysis towards the side of brainstem lesion
  • Weber Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, pupillary dilation) + contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).
  • Millard-Gubler Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis (No gaze paralysis - differentiates it from Foville syndrome) (Option A ruled out)
  • Benedikt Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN III palsy + contralateral ataxia and tremor (red nucleus involvement). (Option B ruled out)
  • Wallenberg Syndrome: Ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia, and hoarseness + contralateral loss of pain/temperature.
  • Locked-In Syndrome: Quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. (Option D ruled out)
  • Raymond Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + contralateral hemiparesis.
  • Dejerine Syndrome: Ipsilateral CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis and impaired proprioception/vibration.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560896/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544268/#

choices.text: Leave IUCD inside and continue pregnancy with prophylactic antibiotics
Leave IUCD inside and continue pregnancy
Remove IUCD immediately and continue with pregnancy
Termination of pregnancy due to risk of infection

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 10-week intrauterine gestation presents to the OPD with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place. The IUCD thread is clearly visible. She expresses her desire to continue the pregnancy. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
If the IUCD thread is visible and the woman wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed immediately to reduce the risk of miscarriage and infection.

  • Pregnancy with an IUCD in situ carries significant risks including miscarriage, intrauterine infection, preterm labor, and intrauterine growth restriction.
  • When the IUCD thread is visible and easily accessible, removal during the first trimester is the recommended management.
  • This significantly improves pregnancy outcomes and reduces complications compared to leaving the IUCD in place.
  • Removal should be performed carefully to avoid disruption of the gestational sac.
  • If the IUCD cannot be safely removed (e.g., no visible thread or device embedded), options depend on IUCD position and patient preference.
  • If removal isn't feasible and the patient still wishes to continue the pregnancy, close monitoring is required.
  • Management algorithm:
    • Thread visible: Remove IUCD immediately.
    • Thread not visible, IUCD not fundal: Attempt ultrasound-guided removal or offer termination.
    • Thread not visible, IUCD in fundus: May consider continuation with IUCD in place under close surveillance.

Explanation of other options:

Leave IUCD inside and continue pregnancy with prophylactic antibiotics (Option A): Not routinely recommended. Antibiotics don't eliminate the risks of septic abortion, miscarriage, or preterm labor. Removal is preferred when the thread is visible.

Leave IUCD inside and continue pregnancy (Option B): Increases risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Since thread is visible, removal is feasible and thus preferred.

Termination of pregnancy due to risk of infection (Option D): Termination is not indicated if the patient wants to continue and the IUCD can be safely removed. It may be considered if IUCD cannot be removed or the patient opts for termination.

questions.text: After a sunburn, a woman experiences pain when lukewarm (40°C) water touches her skin during a shower. Which receptors are activated, and what is the explanation for her pain?
questions.solution:
The woman experienced pain from lukewarm water due to allodynia, where normally non-painful stimuli (like lukewarm water) become painful after a sunburn.

  • The receptors activated were innocuous thermal receptors, which normally detect non-harmful temperatures, but their sensitivity was heightened due to the sunburn, leading to the sensation of pain.

Explanation for other options:

Thermal nociceptors and nociceptive pain (Option A):
