The pleural fluid profile is consistent with exudative pleural effusion, and among the options given, tuberculosis is the most likely cause.

  • The provided pleural fluid analysis shows a pleural protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5 and a pleural LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.4, which are indicative of exudative pleural effusion, as per Light's criteria.

Light's Criteria for Exudative Effusion:

  • Pleural fluid is considered exudative if any one of the following is true:
    • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
    • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
    • Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 the upper limit of normal serum LDH
  • The presence of an exudative effusion narrows down the differential diagnosis to conditions causing pleural inflammation, such as:
    • Tuberculosis
    • Malignancy
    • Pneumonia (parapneumonic effusion)
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., RA, SLE)

Tuberculous Pleuritis:

  • A common cause of exudative pleural effusion, especially in endemic regions.
  • Typically presented with lymphocyte-predominant fluid, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA >40 IU/L), and interferon gamma (>140 pg/mL).
  • May also have low glucose and high protein levels.

Reference:

://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4753987/#sec4

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448189/#

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8578877/#

questions.text: A patient presents with dysuria and increased frequency of urination. He has a known history of recurrent urinary tract infections caused by Proteus species. A radiographic image reveals a renal calculus.
questions.solution:
Calcium phosphate stones are radiopaque and often associated with infections by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, which alkalinize the urine.

  • Infections with Proteus species (urease-producing bacteria) increase the urinary pH by converting urea to ammonia.
  • This creates an alkaline environment favorable for the precipitation of calcium phosphate stones, especially apatite-type, or even struvite stones in some cases.
  • These stones are radiopaque and appear clearly on plain radiographs.
  • Though struvite stones are more classic for staghorn formations, calcium phosphate stones are also associated with chronic infection and appear radiopaque.
  • Hence, given the infection with Proteus and radiographic findings, calcium phosphate stones are the most likely diagnosis in this clinical context.

Explanation of other options:

Cysteine (Option B): Cystine stones result from cystinuria and are usually faintly radiopaque. They are not linked to infections with Proteus.

Uric acid (Option C): Uric acid stones are radiolucent, not visible on plain X-rays, and occur in acidic urine. They are not typically associated with infections like Proteus.

Xanthine (Option D): Xanthine stones are rare, occur in hereditary xanthinuria, and are typically radiolucent. They have no relation to infections or Proteus.

questions.text: A 37-week pregnant woman with a breech presentation is being evaluated for external cephalic version (ECV). Which of the following is not a contraindication for ECV?
questions.solution:
Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV; the procedure can be safely attempted in first-time mothers under appropriate clinical settings.

  • External Cephalic Version (ECV) is a procedure used to turn a fetus from breech to cephalic presentation by manual manipulation through the maternal abdomen.
  • It is generally attempted around 37 weeks of gestation when the baby is mature, but before labor begins.
  • Prerequisites for ECV:
    • Singleton pregnancy
    • Adequate amniotic fluid
    • Intact membranes
    • Reactive NST (Non-stress test)
    • No contraindications to vaginal delivery
  • Contraindications for ECV include:
    • Absolute:
      • Placenta previa (risk of hemorrhage)
      • Previous classical cesarean scar or uterine rupture risk
      • Multiple pregnancy (e.g., twins)
    • Relative:
      • PROM (risk of infection and cord prolapse)
      • Oligohydramnios
      • Fetal compromise
      • Uterine anomalies
  • Being a primigravida is not a contraindication.
  • While multiparous women generally have higher success rates, ECV is routinely and safely attempted in primigravidas as well.

Explanation of other options:

Placenta previa (Option A): Absolute contraindication due to risk of bleeding when manipulating the uterus.

Twin pregnancy (Option B): Contraindicated as manual rotation of one fetus may affect the position of the second, increasing risk.

PROM (Option D): Contraindicated due to risks of cord prolapse, infection, and reduced amniotic fluid, which hinders manipulation.

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency after a road traffic accident (RTA) with chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X-ray was done. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Paradoxical breathing is observed in flail chest, which typically results from multiple rib fractures following blunt trauma, as seen in this patient.

  • In this scenario, a road traffic accident (RTA) patient with chest pain and dyspnea following trauma and imaging suggestive of multiple adjacent rib fractures likely has a flail chest.
  • Flail chest occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, resulting in a free-floating chest segment.
  • This segment exhibits paradoxical movement:
    • Inward movement during inspiration (while the rest of the chest expands)
    • Outward movement during expiration (while the rest of the chest contracts)
  • This abnormal motion disrupts normal ventilation mechanics, leading to:
    • Hypoventilation
    • Mediastinal flutter (which may cause cardiovascular compromise)
    • Pendular air movement (air shunts between lungs inefficiently)
  • Management of flail chest includes:
    • Analgesia to relieve pain and promote effective breathing
    • Oxygen supplementation
    • Intercostal chest drain (if pneumothorax/hemothorax present)
    • Intubation with positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) if respiratory failure occurs
    • Rib fixation in selected severe cases

Explanation of other options:

Cheyne Stokes (Option A): Characterized by cyclic crescendo-decrescendo respirations with apnea. Seen in congestive heart failure and central nervous system disorders-not associated with trauma or flail chest.

Biot (Option B): Irregular breaths with intermittent apnea, usually due to brainstem injury or raised intracranial pressure, not trauma-induced.

Kussmaul (Option C): Deep, rapid breathing seen in metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), not typical of thoracic trauma or rib fractures.

questions.text: What is the earliest age at which a unilateral cleft lip in a newborn can be corrected?
questions.solution:
Unilateral cleft lip repair is ideally performed at 5-6 months of age, ensuring adequate weight gain and tissue maturity.

  • Cleft lip repair is generally timed based on the "Rule of 10s":
    • At least 10 weeks of age
    • 10 pounds in weight
    • 10 g/dL hemoglobin
  • This rule helps minimize anesthesia-related risks and ensures optimal healing.
  • In practice, definitive surgical repair of the unilateral cleft lip is performed around 5 to 6 months of age, after sufficient facial growth and weight gain have occurred.
  • This allows for better cosmetic and functional outcomes with reduced complications.
  • Earlier correction also promotes better feeding, speech development, and social interaction.
  • Timing of repair:

questions.text: What is the expected finding in a patient with the following CXR?
questions.solution:
Flail chest causes paradoxical breathing due to a free-floating chest wall segment that moves opposite to normal during respiration.

  • Flail chest is a traumatic condition resulting from fractures of three or more consecutive ribs in at least two places, creating a flail segment that becomes mechanically independent from the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This segment moves inward during inspiration (when negative pressure draws air in) and outward during expiration, which is the opposite of normal chest wall motion-this is termed paradoxical breathing.
  • This paradoxical motion leads to:
    • Impaired ventilation (due to ineffective pressure generation)
    • Increased dead space and hypoventilation
    • Risk of pulmonary contusion, edema, and atelectasis
    • Clinical features like chest pain, respiratory distress, and tachypnea
  • Diagnosis is suspected clinically and confirmed with imaging:
    • Chest X-ray shows rib fractures
    • CT scan with 3D reconstruction is more sensitive and specific
  • Management includes:
    • Pain control (nerve blocks, epidural)
    • Oxygen supplementation
    • Non-invasive or mechanical ventilation in severe cases
    • Surgical rib fixation in select patients

Explanation of other options:

Kussmaul breathing (Option A): Deep, rapid breathing due to metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis); unrelated to trauma or chest wall mechanics.

Apneustic breathing (Option C): Abnormal breathing pattern with prolonged inspiration seen in pons lesions; not associated with rib fractures.

Bronchial breathing (Option D): High-pitched breath sounds heard over areas of lung consolidation (e.g., pneumonia); not related to chest wall trauma.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534090/

questions.text: Non-clinical question: Which of the following antibodies are associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Celiac disease is associated with anti-tTG (Anti-tissue transglutaminase).


Explanation for other options:

ANCA (Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies) (Option B) is associated with vasculitides, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (C-ANCA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (P-ANCA). They have no role in the diagnosis of celiac disease.

ASCA (Anti-Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Antibodies) (Option C) is commonly associated with Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. They are not linked to celiac disease, which involves immune-mediated small bowel damage due to gluten.

AMA (Anti-Mitochondrial Antibodies) (Option D) is a hallmark of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), a chronic liver disease affecting the bile ducts. They have no relevance to celiac disease.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included in the school health program under Ayushman Bharat?
questions.solution:
Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) tablets are provided weekly, not monthly, under the Ayushman Bharat scheme to prevent anaemia in school-aged children.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health

  • Comprehensive health care for children from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays (4Ds). (Option B ruled out)
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cos,t including surgeries.

Anaemia Mukt Bharat - Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation) (Option D)

  • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink colour. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of February of every year)
  • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid, and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole. (Option C ruled out)

Menstrual hygiene management: (Option A ruled out)

  • Sanitary pads are provided to girls
  • Usually in rural areas

Nutritional Services:

PM POSHAN (POshan SHAkti Nirman) Scheme

  • Previously called as National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools (Mid-Day Meal Scheme) (Option D)
  • Provides one hot cooked meal (⅓ Calories, ½ protein) to school children studying in Classes I-VIII in Government and Government-aided schools. To prevent dropouts.

Reference:

  1. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
  2. anaemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) | National Health Mission, Tamil Nadu, Department of Health & Family Welfar,e Govt. of Tamil Nadu, India
  3. Operational Guidelines for Weekly IFA Supplementation Programme for the Community-Based Intervention Guidelines for Anganwadi Workers
  4. PM Poshan

choices.text: Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient
Beta blockers are to be given for rate control if the patient is intolerant to calcium channel blockers
IV digoxin for ventricular rate control

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, she has bilateral basal crackles and an irregularly irregular pulse. ECG done is shown below. Which of the following management methods is least useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular ventricular rate , suspecting atrial fibrillation with acute decompensated heart failure. Beta-blockers are not preferred in acute decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effect, which may worsen cardiac output.

  • This patient presents with acute atrial fibrillation (AF) and signs of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF)-dyspnea, basal crackles, and irregularly irregular pulse.
  • Management in this setting prioritizes rate control, rhythm control, and stroke prevention through anticoagulation.
  • In acute settings with hemodynamic instability, synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice to rapidly restore sinus rhythm.
  • In stable patients with ADHF, rate control is preferred initially.
  • However, beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers (like diltiazem/verapamil) should be avoided in the acute decompensated phase due to their negative inotropic effect, which can reduce myocardial contractility and worsen heart failure.
  • Therefore, giving beta blockers when calcium channel blockers are not tolerated is not appropriate in this setting.
  • In contrast, IV digoxin can be used for rate control in AF with heart failure, especially when systolic function is compromised, as it has minimal impact on contractility acutely.
  • Additionally, Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) are essential in AF to reduce the risk of thromboembolic complications, such as stroke.

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient (Option A): Appropriate and often life-saving in AF with hemodynamic instability. This is the treatment of choice in acute decompensated heart failure with AF when the patient is unstable.

Direct oral anticoagulants (Option B): Crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications like stroke in patients with AF. DOACs are preferred over warfarin unless contraindicated.

IV digoxin for ventricular rate control (Option D): Useful in controlling ventricular rate in AF when beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated, particularly in patients with heart failure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with an ovarian solid-cystic mass on ultrasound. Which combination of tumor markers is most appropriate for further evaluation of the likely ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
These markers collectively help evaluate the most common ovarian tumors in young females, particularly germ cell tumors like yolk sac tumor, choriocarcinoma, and dysgerminoma.

  • In young women (especially under 30), the most common ovarian tumors are germ cell tumors rather than epithelial ovarian cancers.
  • The appropriate tumor markers help in diagnosing and monitoring specific subtypes:
    • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): Elevated in yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors).
    • β-hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin): Elevated in choriocarcinoma and embryonal carcinoma.
    • LDH (Lactate dehydrogenase): Elevated in dysgerminoma, the most common malignant germ cell tumor in this age group.
    • CA-125: Typically elevated in epithelial ovarian cancer, but still assessed to rule out rare epithelial malignancy or in case of mixed pathology.
  • This combination is routinely ordered when evaluating ovarian masses in adolescents and young women to cover all common germ cell tumors.


Explanation of other options:

CA125, AFP, HCG, CEA (Option A): CEA is associated with gastrointestinal malignancies (e.g., colorectal cancer); not useful for evaluating ovarian germ cell tumors.

CA125, AFP, HCG, CA19-9 (Option B): CA19-9 is primarily elevated in pancreatic and gastrointestinal malignancies-not in ovarian germ cell tumors.

CA125, AFP, HCG, CA15-3 (Option D): CA15-3 is a tumor marker for breast cancer, not relevant in evaluating ovarian masses in young women.

questions.text: Based on the constituents, identify the fluid given to post-operative patients:
questions.solution:
The given composition closely matches Ringer lactate, an isotonic fluid commonly used postoperatively to maintain electrolyte balance and prevent metabolic acidosis.

  • Ringer Lactate (also called Hartmann's Solution) is a crystalloid isotonic solution designed to mimic plasma electrolyte composition.
  • It contains:
    • Na⁺ - 130 mmol/L
    • Cl⁻ - 109 mmol/L
    • K⁺ - 4 mmol/L
    • Ca₂⁺ - 1.5 mmol/L
    • Lactate - 28 mmol/L
    • Osmolality ~273 mOsm/kg
  • This makes it ideal for perioperative and postoperative fluid replacement, especially since lactate acts as a buffer by being metabolized into bicarbonate, which prevents hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, unlike normal saline.
  • Ringer lactate is rapidly cleared due to suppression of ADH, promoting diuresis, making it suitable for patients at risk of volume overload.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Haemaccel (Option B): It is a colloid solution containing gelatin and electrolytes, mainly used in shock or blood loss. It is not routinely used for postoperative maintenance fluids and doesn't match the above composition.

Isolyte P (Option C): Contains more calcium (2.7 mEq/L) and includes magnesium and bicarbonate not present in the given table. It is typically used for pediatric maintenance rather than adult post-op care.

Isolyte M (Option D): Has a higher sodium content (~140 mEq/L), more potassium (5 mEq/L), and acetate instead of lactate as a buffer. It doesn't match the given profile.

Reference:

Intravenous fluids - Pocket Book of Hospital Care for Children - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: In the health education model with first step as awareness and second step as motivation, what is the third step?

A 36-year-old woman presents with anemia, a platelet count of 25,000/mm³, and prolonged prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time. A peripheral blood smear image is provided. Which fusion gene is most likely involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Based on the above histology, which shows faggot cells containing Auer rods, which is a feature of Acute myeloid leukaemia (M3), the fusion gene PML-RARA is formed due to t(15:17).


Explanation for other options:

RUNX1-RUNX1T1 (Option B) is found in AML with t(8;21). It typically presents with anaemia and neutropenia, but platelet levels are normal or slightly low. Coagulopathy is uncommon.

INV(16) (Option C) is associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils. Coagulopathy is rare, and severe thrombocytopenia is not typical.

IGH-NSD2 (Option D) is seen in multiple myeloma with t(4;14). Features include bone pain and renal dysfunction, not coagulopathy or low platelets.

questions.text: A 28-year-old asymptomatic male undergoes routine medical evaluation for job recruitment. His ECG reveals a PR interval of 0.21 seconds, but no dropped beats or irregular rhythms are noted. He has no history of cardiovascular disease and no symptoms like palpitations or syncope. What is the most appropriate diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
A PR interval >0.20 seconds with no dropped beats is diagnostic of first-degree AV block.

  • First-degree AV block is defined by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) on ECG, representing delayed conduction through the AV node or proximal conduction system.
  • Importantly, every P wave is followed by a QRS complex, indicating that conduction is delayed but not blocked.
  • Etiologies include:
    • Increased vagal tone (in athletes or young individuals)
    • Fibrosis of the conduction system in the elderly
    • Myocardial ischemia, MI
    • Drugs (e.g., beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
    • Infectious/inflammatory diseases (e.g., Lyme disease, rheumatic fever, myocarditis)
    • Infiltrative diseases (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis)
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually asymptomatic
    • Rarely, patients with very prolonged PR intervals may experience symptoms due to atrial contraction occurring too early before ventricular filling ("pseudo-pacemaker syndrome")
  • ECG Features:
    • PR interval >0.20 seconds
    • Regular rhythm
    • No dropped QRS complexes
  • Management:
    • Typically no treatment is needed
    • Periodic follow-up with ECG
    • Consider pacing only if associated with symptoms or other conduction disease

ECG's of Heart Blocks


Explanation of other options:

Normal ECG (Option B): The upper limit of a normal PR interval is 0.20 seconds; a PR of 0.21 seconds is prolonged, thus not a normal finding.

2nd-degree block (Option C): Characterized by intermittent dropped QRS complexes:

  • Mobitz I (Wenckebach): Progressive PR lengthening followed by a dropped beat.
  • Mobitz II: Sudden dropped beats without PR prolongation. Neither are seen in this case.

Complete heart block (Option D): There is no AV conduction; the atria and ventricles beat independently, and PR intervals are variable or unrelated. This is not consistent with a constant prolonged PR interval and 1:1 conduction.

Reference:

First-Degree Heart Block - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

1st degree heart block: Causes, symptoms, and treatment

questions.text: Identify the grade of the condition given in the image below ?
questions.solution:
Grade IV pressure sores involve full-thickness tissue loss with exposure of muscle, bone, or supporting structures, which matches the findings in the image.

  • Pressure sores, also called decubitus ulcers or bedsores, are localized injuries to skin and underlying tissue due to prolonged pressure.
  • The National Pressure Injury Advisory Panel (NPIAP) classifies them into four grades based on severity:
    • Grade I: Non-blanchable erythema with intact skin.
    • Grade II: Partial-thickness skin loss involving epidermis and dermis.
    • Grade III: Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous fat but not extending to underlying fascia or structures.
    • Grade IV: Full-thickness tissue loss with exposure of muscle, bone, tendon, or joint capsule.
  • The visible deep ulceration with exposed muscle and/or bone is classic for Grade IV, the most severe type.

choices.text: Ampulla - As it has a uniform thickness of muscle
Ampulla - As it is the widest part
Ampulla-Isthmus junction - As it is the site of fertilization
Isthmus - As it is the narrowest part

questions.text: A woman is undergoing elective tubal ligation for permanent contraception. Which is the most common site selected for ligation, and what is the reason for choosing this site?
questions.solution:
The isthmus is chosen for tubal ligation because its narrow diameter ensures effective blockage and lower failure rates.

  • The isthmus is the narrow, straight portion of the fallopian tube located closest to the uterus.
  • It is the most common and preferred site for tubal ligation (tubectomy) because:
    • It is easy to access surgically.
    • Its narrow lumen allows more secure occlusion, reducing the chance of recanalization or tubal failure.
    • There is less vascularity in this region, which decreases intraoperative bleeding risks.
  • Tubal ligation procedures such as Pomeroy's, Parkland, or Irving methods are typically done at the isthmic segment.
  • Sterilization effectiveness is highest when this site is targeted.

Explanation of other options:

Ampulla - As it has a uniform thickness of muscle (Option A): While the ampulla has a uniform muscle layer, this is not relevant for sterilization. The site's width makes it less suitable for effective occlusion.

Ampulla - As it is the widest part (Option B): Its wide diameter actually increases the risk of failure, as blocking a wider tube is less secure.

Ampulla-Isthmus junction - As it is the site of fertilization (Option C): Although fertilization typically occurs here, ligation at this site is not preferred due to anatomical variability and higher technical difficulty.

questions.text: Which indicator is defined by a formula that uses the number of maternal deaths as the numerator and the total number of women of reproductive age as the denominator?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-related deaths are counted up to 6 weeks (OR) 42 days postpartum.



Perinatal mortality ratio (Option D): This term is not commonly used. If used, it might be mistaken for the perinatal mortality rate, but it does not apply to maternal deaths or reproductive-age women.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted with acute exacerbation. He is placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. During ventilation, his oxygen saturation begins to fall consistently. On auscultation, vesicular breath sounds are heard on the right side, and chest X-ray was done and shown below. What is the most likely finding on auscultation of the left side of the chest?
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray reveals a hyperlucent left hemithorax with absent vascular markings and mediastinal shift to the right.

In left-sided pneumothorax, air in the pleural space prevents transmission of breath sounds, resulting in absent breath sounds on auscultation.

  • In a patient with COPD on mechanical ventilation, the sudden drop in oxygen saturation, along with hyperlucency on chest X-ray and absent vascular markings, strongly suggests the development of a pneumothorax, specifically on the left side in this case.
  • Mechanical ventilation, especially with positive pressure, increases the risk of barotrauma, which may cause rupture of already fragile lung tissue (common in emphysematous lungs of COPD patients), leading to a secondary spontaneous or tension pneumothorax.

Classic signs of pneumothorax:

  • Inspection: Asymmetric chest movement, respiratory distress
  • Palpation: Reduced/absent tactile fremitus on affected side
  • Percussion: Hyperresonant note on the side of pneumothorax
  • Auscultation: Absent or markedly reduced breath sounds over the affected side
  • Other signs: Tracheal/mediastinal shift (if tension pneumothorax), hypoxemia, hypotension

Explanation of other options:

Bronchial breath sounds (Option B): Bronchial breath sounds are heard over areas of lung consolidation (e.g., pneumonia), not in pneumothorax, where the lung is collapsed and displaced by air in the pleural space.

Increased vesicular breath sounds (Option C): Vesicular breath sounds are normal and may be slightly increased over hyperinflated but aerated lungs; in pneumothorax, breath sounds are typically absent, not increased.

Increased vocal fremitus (Option D): Fremitus is increased in consolidated lung, but decreased or absent in pneumothorax due to the insulating effect of free air in the pleural cavity.

Reference:

https://pubs.rsna.org/doi/abs/10.1148/radiol.2282020524?journalCode=radiology

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pneumothorax

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17419871/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11464087/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5849448/

questions.text: A 6-week-old neonate was brought with complaints of recurrent vomiting. USG was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound shows the classic "doughnut sign" of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in a neonate with non-bilious projectile vomiting.

  • Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) is a condition characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in infants between 3 to 6 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting.
  • On examination, a firm, mobile, olive-like mass may be palpated in the epigastric region.
  • Ultrasound is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • The characteristic sonographic finding is the "target sign" or "doughnut sign" on the transverse section, which represents a thickened hypoechoic muscle layer surrounding the echogenic mucosa.
  • Diagnostic measurements include:
    • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • Additional imaging with a barium meal (if needed) may show signs like the string sign, railroad track sign, or double track sign.



  • Metabolic abnormalities typically include:
    • Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis (due to persistent vomiting of gastric HCl and volume loss)

Explanation of other options:

Sigmoid volvulus (Option A): Seen in older children or adults, not neonates. USG is not diagnostic; classic finding is the "coffee bean sign" on X-ray due to twisted sigmoid colon.


Duodenal atresia (Option B): Causes bilious vomiting (not non-bilious), and USG or X-ray typically shows the "double bubble" sign, not a doughnut/target sign.


Annular pancreas (Option D): May cause duodenal obstruction but does not produce the doughnut sign on ultrasound. The pancreas encircles the duodenum and may be seen on CT or MRI rather than USG alone.

questions.text: Persistent occipito-posterior (OP) face-to-pubis delivery is most likely to be seen in which pelvic type?
questions.solution:
Persistent occipito-posterior (OP) and face-to-pubis deliveries are most commonly associated with the anthropoid pelvis, due to its elongated anteroposterior diameter.

  • The anthropoid pelvis has:
    • An oval-shaped inlet elongated in the anteroposterior direction
    • Straight side walls, wide sacrosciatic notches
    • A narrow subpubic angle
  • This configuration:
    • Favors the occiput of the fetus remaining posterior rather than rotating anteriorly
    • Makes persistent OP positions and face-to-pubis deliveries more likely
    • These deliveries are usually longer and more difficult due to malrotation and the need for greater head flexion or deflexion

questions.text: A patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dysuria and sterile pyuria. The cystoscopy image provided below indicates what condition?
questions.solution:
Golf hole ureter is a classical cystoscopic finding in genitourinary tuberculosis, reflecting fibrotic contraction around the ureteric orifice.

  • In genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB), especially in chronic cases, the bladder becomes fibrotic and contracted due to ongoing inflammation and healing by fibrosis.
  • This leads to changes in the appearance of the ureteric orifices seen during cystoscopy.
  • One of the hallmark findings is the "golf hole ureter", a sharply demarcated, rigid, gaping ureteric orifice caused by periureteric fibrosis.
  • This case is also supported clinically by:
    • History of TB
    • Dysuria
    • Sterile pyuria (WBCs in urine without bacterial growth)
  • Additional findings of GUTB:
    • "Thimble bladder": contracted, non-compliant bladder on imaging
    • Beaded vas deferens or scrotal sinuses in male genital involvement
    • Calcifications or irregular ureteric narrowing on IVU or CECT
    • Early calyceal changes: "moth-eaten" calyces
  • Investigations:
    • Urine for AFB (acid-fast bacilli) or PCR
    • CECT urography or IVU
    • Cystoscopy (as shown in this case)
  • Treatment:
    • Antitubercular Therapy (ATT) is the cornerstone
    • Surgery for complications like strictures or severe fibrosis

Explanation of other options:

Ureterocele (Option B): This is a congenital dilation of the distal ureter protruding into the bladder. On imaging, it shows the 'cobra head sign.' Cystoscopically, it appears as a ballooning mass, not a gaping rigid orifice.



Hunner lesions (Option C): These are seen in interstitial cystitis, presenting as ulcerative patches in the bladder mucosa. They are unrelated to TB and do not involve the ureteric orifices.

Urethral stricture (Option D): Refers to narrowing of the urethra, not involving the ureteric orifices or bladder mucosa. Symptoms include weak urinary stream and incomplete emptying but no golf-hole appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of PQLI?
questions.solution:
The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is an indicator used to measure the quality of life or well-being in a country. Unlike the Human Development Index (HDI), which considers economic factors, the PQLI focuses solely on basic physical needs.


EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

questions.text: Identify the degree of uterine prolapse
questions.solution:
Degree 3 uterine prolapse is characterized by descent of the uterus such that it protrudes through the vaginal opening but does not extend entirely beyond the vulva.

  • Uterine prolapse occurs when pelvic floor muscles and ligaments become weak and are no longer able to support the uterus, leading to its descent into or through the vagina.
  • Prolapse is classified into four degrees:
    • 1st Degree: Uterus descends into the upper two-thirds of the vagina. (Option A ruled out)
    • 2nd Degree: Uterus reaches the vaginal introitus. (Options B ruled out)
    • 3rd Degree: Uterus protrudes out of the introitus but remains partially within the vulva.
    • 4th Degree (Procidentia): Uterus is completely outside the vaginal canal. (Option D ruled out)
  • In Degree 3, as seen in the case and image, the uterus bulges visibly through the vaginal introitus, often causing discomfort, a dragging sensation, or a visible mass.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past 5 days. He gives a history of heavy alcohol consumption. Blood investigations reveal amylase and lipase levels elevated five times the upper limit of normal. He received 2 liters of intravenous saline in the last 24 hours. Chest X-ray is shown below:


Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral lung opacities. Acute pancreatitis can lead to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (ARDS) due to systemic inflammation and capillary leakage, seen as bilateral diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray.

  • This patient has acute pancreatitis, likely alcohol-induced, with classical symptoms (epigastric pain radiating to the back) and elevated amylase/lipase.
  • The chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral opacities, which, in the setting of acute pancreatitis, are most consistent with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, specifically acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • Mechanism:
    • Acute pancreatitis leads to systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
    • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6, IL-8) increase capillary permeability in pulmonary vasculature.
    • This leads to protein-rich alveolar edema, not caused by heart failure - hence non-cardiogenic.
    • ARDS is a known complication of pancreatitis.
  • Berlin Definition of ARDS:
    • Timing: Within 1 week of a known insult (e.g., pancreatitis)
    • Chest imaging: Bilateral opacities
    • Origin: Not explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload
    • Oxygenation: PaO2/FiO2 ratio used to classify severity
  • Management:
    • Supportive care with lung-protective ventilation
    • Conservative fluid management
    • Prone positioning, high PEEP in moderate/severe cases
    • Avoid overhydration, which can worsen pulmonary edema

Explanation of other options:

Aspiration pneumonia (Option A): Typically causes localized infiltrates (often in the right lower lobe) with a history of vomiting, altered sensorium, or seizures. It doesn't match the diffuse bilateral opacities seen here.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option C): Presents with tiny, uniform nodules ("millet seed" pattern) and systemic features like fever, weight loss, night sweats. It's a chronic illness, not acute, and unrelated to acute pancreatitis.


Bilateral pulmonary embolism (Option D): Presents with acute dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxia, and possibly clear chest X-ray (may show Westermark sign or Hampton's hump, rarely bilateral infiltrates). PE is not typically associated with pancreatitis or diffuse infiltrates.


Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7997862/

questions.text: A patient presents with a new 2 cm black nodular mass near an episiotomy scar that is painful and expands during menstruation. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis involving a scar site presents as a painful nodular mass that enlarges cyclically with menstruation.

  • Endometriosis is defined as the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity.
  • When endometrial tissue implants in surgical scars-such as an episiotomy site-it can lead to scar endometriosis.
  • These lesions respond to hormonal changes, causing cyclical pain and swelling during menstruation.
  • On examination, they often appear as firm, pigmented nodules and may mimic other pathologies like tumors or granulomas.
  • Scar endometriosis should be suspected in any reproductive-aged woman with a history of obstetric or gynecologic surgery who presents with localized pain and a mass that fluctuates with her cycle.

Diagnosis Guidelines:

  • Current guidelines do not require histologic confirmation to diagnose endometriosis, often based on clinical presentation and macroscopic findings during laparoscopy.
  • Macroscopic Findings:
    • Powder-burn or Gunshot Lesions: Dark, blackish-bluish puckered lesions on the peritoneal surface.
    • Clear Vesicles: Small, blister-like lesions on the ovarian surface or peritoneum.
    • Red Polypoidal Lesions: Red, polyp-like, vascularised lesions.
    • White Scarred Lesions: White, scar-like areas with fibrosis and few blood vessels.
    • Yellow-brown Peritoneal Discoloration: Indicates hemosiderin deposition and chronic endometriosis.
  • Correlation of Gross Appearance with Microscopic Findings
    • Red Lesions: Vascularized, indicating active endometriotic tissue.
    • White Lesions: Fibrosis with few vessels, suggesting chronic or scarred tissue.
  • Histologic Examination
    • Hemosiderin Deposition: Common in histologic samples, indicating prior bleeding within the lesion.
    • Histologic Diagnosis Criteria: The presence of both endometrial glands and stroma is required to confirm endometriosis.

Explanation of other options:

Melanoma (Option B): A pigmented, possibly nodular skin cancer, but it does not fluctuate with the menstrual cycle and is typically painless in early stages.

Foreign body granuloma (Option C): Results from retained suture or tissue, forming a firm, non-pigmented lump; typically non-cyclic and non-menstruation-related.

Inclusion cyst (Option D): A painless, smooth, epithelial-lined cyst resulting from trauma or surgery; does not enlarge or become painful during menstruation.

questions.text: A patient presented with flank pain and hematuria. The histology image is shown below. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Chromophobe RCC is identified histologically by large polygonal cells with pale cytoplasm, distinct cell membranes, and perinuclear halos.

  • Chromophobe Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) is a distinct subtype of RCC that originates from intercalated cells of the collecting duct.
  • It typically has a better prognosis than clear cell and collecting duct carcinomas.
  • Histological Features:
    • Pale or eosinophilic cytoplasm
    • Prominent cell borders ("plant cell" or "vegetable cell" appearance)
    • Perinuclear halos
    • Raisinoid nuclei (irregular, wrinkled nuclear contours)
  • These cells often appear as sheets or nests with clear cytoplasm and thickened membranes, giving them a unique and recognizable appearance.

questions.text: A 37-weeks pregnant woman with a mechanical prosthetic heart valve on warfarin presents for a routine antenatal check-up. She is asymptomatic and reports no bleeding or contractions
questions.solution:
At term, warfarin should be switched to LMWH to reduce the risk of fetal and maternal bleeding during labor.

  • Warfarin is teratogenic and crosses the placenta, especially dangerous during organogenesis in the first trimester and during delivery due to fetal intracranial hemorrhage.
  • By 36-37 weeks of gestation, warfarin must be discontinued and replaced with LMWH to ensure safety for both mother and fetus in preparation for labor or cesarean section.
  • For women with mechanical heart valves, anticoagulation must continue-but with a safer agent like LMWH, which does not cross the placenta and has a shorter half-life, allowing temporary discontinuation just before delivery (usually 6-12 hours).
  • This strategy balances maternal protection from thrombosis while minimizing fetal/neonatal bleeding risks.

Summary Flowchart: Anticoagulation in Pregnancy with Mechanical Valves

First Trimester:
→ LMWH (to avoid teratogenicity)

Second Trimester:
→ Warfarin (if <5 mg/day, relatively safer)

At 36-37 Weeks:
→ Switch back to LMWH (to avoid bleeding during delivery)

Postpartum:
→ Restart warfarin after delivery

  • Regular monitoring (PT-INR for warfarin, anti-Xa for LMWH if needed) is essential throughout.
  • Switching to LMWH near term is the best strategy to ensure both maternal protection and fetal safety during delivery.

Explanation of other options:

Immediate induction of labor (Option B): Induction without adjusting anticoagulation increases risk of hemorrhage. Anticoagulation needs to be optimized first before considering induction.

Immediate LSCS (Option C): C-section isn't indicated just for being on warfarin. Surgery would need anticoagulation to be managed (stop warfarin, use LMWH). Immediate LSCS without planning is risky.

Continue the same (Option D): Continuing warfarin at term is dangerous due to the risk of fetal bleeding, particularly intracranial hemorrhage during delivery.

choices.text: Ankle clonus in the right foot
Proprioception lost in the left leg
Pain and temperature were lost in the right leg

questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffered a road traffic accident (RTA). A few days later, he presents with exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and increased right knee jerk. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
These findings are consistent with an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.

Clonus is a classic sign of upper motor neuron lesions, typically seen along with hyperreflexia and extensor plantar response.

  • The signs described-exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk) and extensor plantar response (Babinski sign)-are characteristic of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion affecting the right side.
  • UMN lesions commonly occur in:
    • Spinal cord trauma
    • Stroke
    • Multiple sclerosis
    • Cerebral palsy
  • One of the hallmark features of UMN lesions is clonus-involuntary rhythmic contractions typically seen at the ankle or patella when the muscle is stretched.
  • Ankle clonus, therefore, is a logical and expected associated finding in this patient with right-sided UMN signs.

Explanation of other options:

Proprioception lost in the left leg (Option B): Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column, which ascends ipsilaterally in the spinal cord and decussates in the medulla. A right-sided spinal cord lesion would impair right-sided proprioception, not left-sided.

Pain and temperature lost in the right leg (Option C): Pain and temperature sensations travel in the spinothalamic tract, which crosses at the level of entry into the spinal cord. A right-sided lesion would affect left-sided pain and temperature sensation, not right.

Fasciculations in the right foot (Option D): Fasciculations are a sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion, not UMN. LMN signs include flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and reduced reflexes; none of which match this case.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537305/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/lower-motor-neuron-lesion

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541082/#

questions.text: A patient with cervical cancer is found to have pelvic sidewall involvement and hydronephrosis on evaluation. What is the stage?
questions.solution:
Stage III B cervical cancer is defined by pelvic sidewall involvement and/or hydronephrosis, both of which are present in this patient.

  • The FIGO 2018 staging system for cervical cancer emphasizes anatomical spread, including the pelvic sidewall and hydronephrosis as critical criteria for Stage III B.
  • Stage III B:
    • Tumor extends to the pelvic sidewall
    • And/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney (not due to other causes)
  • In this patient:
    • Pelvic sidewall involvement → suggests extensive local invasion.
    • Hydronephrosis → due to ureteral compression/obstruction by tumor, a hallmark of advanced disease.
  • Hence, the diagnosis is Stage III B cervical cancer.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cervical-cancer-staging-1

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common mutation associated with the microscopy image of the thyroid shown?
questions.solution: The given histological image shows papillary projections and optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei), indicating Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC), which is associated with the BRAF mutation.

questions.text: What is this grid system used for?
questions.solution:
The POP-Q grid system is a standardized method used to assess the severity and classification of pelvic organ prolapse.

  • The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is the most widely accepted and standardized method for evaluating and documenting pelvic organ prolapse.
  • It uses specific reference points on the vaginal walls and cervix in relation to the hymen to assign a prolapse stage from 0 to IV.
  • The system allows objective, reproducible measurements that help clinicians compare prolapse severity over time or pre- and post-treatment.
  • POP-Q Staging:
    • Stage 0: No prolapse.
    • Stage I: Most distal portion of prolapse is >1 cm above the hymen.
    • Stage II: Leading edge of prolapse is ≤1 cm above or below the hymen.
    • Stage III: Leading edge is >1 cm below hymen but not complete eversion.
    • Stage IV: Complete eversion of the total vaginal length.
  • This system improves communication between providers and guides surgical or conservative management of prolapse.


Explanation of other options:

Vulvar cancer (Option B): This is staged using FIGO or TNM systems, not POP-Q.

Endometrial cancer (Option C): Endometrial cancer staging is done surgically based on FIGO criteria, not prolapse quantification systems.

Abruption placenta (Option D): Abruptio placentae is a clinical obstetric emergency assessed based on symptoms and imaging, not by any pelvic organ measurement grid.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents in labor with active genital ulcers, likely of infectious etiology such as Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).
questions.solution:
LSCS is recommended to prevent vertical transmission of infection (especially HSV) from mother to neonate during vaginal delivery in the presence of active genital ulcers.

  • Genital ulcers in pregnancy are often caused by HSV-2.
  • If the mother has active lesions at the time of delivery, vertical transmission of the virus can occur, leading to neonatal herpes, which has high morbidity and mortality.
  • Neonatal herpes can manifest as:
    • Localized skin, eye, mouth (SEM) infection
    • Disseminated infection
    • Central nervous system involvement
  • To prevent transmission:
    • LSCS is the preferred mode of delivery when active lesions or prodromal symptoms are present at the time of labor.
  • Timing: LSCS is ideally performed within 4-6 hours of membrane rupture to minimize viral exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Classic Caesarean Section (Option B): Involves a vertical uterine incision, reserved for rare indications (e.g., transverse lie with back down, placenta previa, or lower uterine segment not developed). Not indicated for genital ulcers.

Vaginal Delivery (Option C): Contraindicated in active genital herpes or suspicious ulcers due to high risk of neonatal HSV infection.

Induction of Labour (Option D): Inducing labor increases risk of prolonged exposure to infection, making it unsafe in the presence of active genital ulcers.

questions.text: What is the typical time between fertilization and implantation in human reproduction?
questions.solution:
Implantation usually occurs about 6-10 days post-fertilization, with the average being 8 days.

  • After fertilization in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, the zygote undergoes mitotic divisions to form a morula and then a blastocyst.
  • This journey takes several days as the embryo moves towards the uterus.
    • Day 3-4 post-fertilization: Morula (12-16 cell stage) enters the uterus.
    • Day 4-5: Blastocyst formation begins.
    • Day 6-7: Blastocyst begins attaching to the endometrial lining.
    • Day 8 (average): Implantation is usually completed or actively ongoing.
  • Thus, 8 days is considered the average time for implantation to begin.

Explanation of other options:

2 days (Option A): Too early for implantation; the zygote is still in the fallopian tube undergoing cleavage.

14 days (Option C): Implantation should already be completed by this time; by now, hCG levels may be detectable in blood.

16 days (Option D): Implantation beyond this point is unlikely; if not implanted by now, the embryo is typically non-viable.

choices.text: Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby, but do not reveal gender to the patient
Check for congenital anomalies, do not check the sex of the fetus
Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby and reveal gender if it is female
Check only routine ANC, and avoid USG

questions.text: A G5P4 woman comes for her first routine sonography. She has four daughters and desires a boy this time, and asks to know the sex of the fetus. According to the PCPNDT Act, which action should a radiologist choose?
questions.solution:
Under the PCPNDT Act, fetal sex determination is prohibited, and the radiologist must focus solely on assessing congenital anomalies without attempting to determine fetal gender.

  • The Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, enacted in India in 1994 and amended in 2003, was introduced to combat female feticide and address the declining sex ratio.
  • It strictly prohibits sex selection and sex determination before or after conception.
  • During routine prenatal ultrasounds, a radiologist is legally obligated to examine fetal growth, viability, and congenital anomalies but is prohibited from determining or recording the fetal sex.
  • Violating this can lead to severe penalties, including suspension of medical license and criminal prosecution.
  • In this case, despite the patient's request due to personal bias (having four daughters), the radiologist must maintain ethical and legal integrity by not attempting to determine or disclose the fetal gender.

Explanation of other options:

Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby, but do not reveal gender to the patient (Option A): Even if the sex is not revealed, determining the sex itself is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, unless it's done under specific medical indications (which are rare).

Check for congenital anomalies, sex of baby and reveal gender if it is female (Option C): This clearly violates the PCPNDT Act by both determining and disclosing the sex of the fetus, regardless of gender.

Check only routine ANC, and avoid USG (Option D): Avoiding ultrasound altogether is not appropriate, as it is essential for routine antenatal care, especially for detecting fetal anomalies.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3498638/
